summary: Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a thief with the rare ability to enter people's dreams and steal their secrets from their subconscious. His skill has made him a hot commodity in the world of corporate espionage but has also cost him everything he loves. Cobb gets a chance at redemption when he is offered a seemingly impossible task: Plant an idea in someone's mind. If he succeeds, it will be the perfect crime, but a dangerous enemy anticipates Cobb's every move.

Inception isn't a film without merit, but does anyone else get the impression that Christopher Nolan is more interested in proving how incredibly intelligent he is than he is about making an entertaining movie or anything closely resembling art?  In the case of Inception, the premise is interesting, the cast is impressive (Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Elliot Page, etc.), and the special effects are periodically spectacular.  However, as with a handful of his other movies, the story becomes convoluted beyond belief (it's a dream…within a dream…within a dream!!), resulting in the characters providing expository dialogue to explain the madness to the dumbfounded audience, giving the whole thing a condescending vibe.  There is a kernel of a great idea here, but Nolan insists on ruining it by showing off his towering intellect.  Thanks for nothing.

Unless you are paying full attention, you are likely to find this a confusing watch. From the moment of the opening scenes, you are drawn into a world where reality and dream are blurred and separating the two is not straightforward. However, after a while everything becomes clear and it is easier to understand what is going on. That is, until the multi layered dream sequence starts. There are some inconsistencies, but overall, very entertaining. The whole premise behind the film is excellent but there is a lot of ambiguity. I would like to have seen more sophisticated storytelling in each layer. The snow scene just appears to have been action for the sake of itself, even though the outcome was vital to the plot. However, the final outcome of the dream sequence is never explained outside of a dream, so we never get to understand if it all paid off. We could go even further and say that we cannot even be sure that the whole thing from beginning to end was just a dream.

This has to be Christopher Nolan's best film to date the visuals, characters & story are all amazing. But while it's really good this film isn't perfect their are some flaws but the flaws can be overlooked like for example their is a lot of exposition in the film but it's necessary since it their to explain the concept of the movie since it involves Dreams which is a weird concept that any normal person would be asking questions about like how do they work?, can this happen?, what happens if I do this?, etc. 

The film is super entertaining their is not a time you will feel bored or feeling like your time is being wasted like the dreams they never get through what's the point of it existing but instead it always begins right in the middle of it. Like in the beginning of the movie we don't have scene of Cobb & Arthur arriving at the party, talk with the other guests, planning a meeting with Saito which finally establishes why we are here. It skips all that & instead has us learning that Saito is in a dream & that he has a secret that's worth stealing right away before we learn all the other info first since we don't start off in the beginning of the dream we start off in the middle of it which has us constantly wondering what happened before this? how did they get into this situation? whenever they enter a dream which gives it one of the most thrilling movie openings of all time & leave anyone watching with excitement on what's going to happen for the rest of the movie.

In the first dream our characters kidnap Fisher which has them having to deal with his security, in the second dream they are already trying to get Fisher to join the team all while the environment of the dream is being moved around with due to gravity of the car chase, In the third dream we are scouting out a military base which has Fishers secret the team has been looking for. Notice how their is no filler here it's all just what we want to see it's made to make sure we don't get bored. But this does sorta make Fisher seem like a boring character that is just a tool for the characters goals but that's where your wrong since they have Earmes infiltrate his legal team but they skip all the boring interview steps & instead put us right in the moment we want to see he we see the relationship Fisher & his father have right away these scenes are also connected with a clear reason & motivation for us being here so it doesn't feel random or out of nowhere. 

The concept of Dreams in this film is also very interesting they aren't bound by any rules or realism through out the film characters are hopping between dreams all the time that differ from one another one minute we could be in a Train than a Plane, Asia, Europe, etc & the weather changes to it could be sunny, rain or snow their is no limitations on what can happen or where which makes the visuals not feel repetitive or all the same every dream is different than the last.

Writer/director Christopher Nolan is one of the most daring filmmakers out there today. He loves to craft intricate narratives ripe with symbolism and thematic layers that you can peel back upon repeated viewings. He is a dreamer with a lot on his mind, more than most other filmmakers. The guy who toyed with chronology and narrative structure in 'Memento', who redefined the possibilities of the comic-book/superhero movie with his cerebral 'Batman' films, has staked his place among the best directors of our time, an artist who creates vivid dreamscapes on silver screens for audiences to take in. With this trippy sci-fi mind-bender, the movie event of the summer and the best film of 2010 so far, he has created perhaps his most elaborate dream yet. This strikingly original, intelligently dense, and wholly absorbing film is an enigma wrapped in a puzzle trapped in a maze. From the first moments to the final "twist" (one that has sparked much debate and analysis) the film pulls you in and casts a dazzling spell. Nolan fills the frame with astonishing visuals--Paris folding in on itself, a city of skyscrapers that crumble into the sea. A gravity-defying fight sequence in a corridor is a serious jaw-dropper. Leonardo DiCaprio is a sturdy, compelling presence that guides us through this dizzying maze. Solid support is provided by the likes of Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Marion Cotillard and Cillian Murphy. As far as popcorn actioners go, this is VERY smart and challenging. Blink, and you'll miss something. But this rewards close attention, and will undoubtedly unravel glorious symbolic riches upon multiple viewings. Like the very idea of "inception" at its core, this film will get inside your head, fester and churn, and stay with you LONG after the end titles disappear. A brilliant masterpiece

*Some people have said that this movie is "overrated," but that is not true- they simply can't understand Chris Nolan's level of brilliance.*
This is my absolute favourite movie. I have seen it 10 times (literally) and have still not gotten sick of it. Christopher Nolan can be described as nothing other than brilliant- absolutely, purely, enchantingly brilliant. His cinematography is always top-notch, but his plots are to die for. There is always something so alluring about his films. INCEPTION is a beautifully complex action-thriller about the art of transporting your consciousness into someone else's mind. You go into their dreams- their secrets are yours to discover- but it all comes at a cost, of course. This movie has some action scenes, some curse words- pretty acute swearing, and will lead you to question a lot of things. Nolan always has an all-star cast that never disappoints, and loves to use Hans Zimmer to do his soundtracks. Hans Zimmer is the perfect composer for Nolan movies- their individual arts of music and cinema combine, leading to a perfect, jaw-dropping movie. This movie will make you feel amazing; invincible. I must warn you, though, this is one of those movies that you have to really think about (Nolan's beautiful brain strikes again). "What is the most resilient parasite? Bacteria? A virus? An intestinal worm? An idea. Resilient, highly contagious. Once an idea has taken hold of the brain it's almost impossible to eradicate." - Dom Cobb, Inception.
A generational scifi-thriller-action packed movie that has you at the edge of your seat from beginning to end. Visually stunning. DiCaprio really delivered in this film.

This is one of my favorite movies but it has flaws that can’t really be ignored. Speaking from personal enjoyment it’s a 10/10 for me but there are a few inconsistencies in the movie’s logic like the kick idea when (spoiler) apparently being in a car that falls off a bridge isn’t enough to wake you up but a chair tipping over immediately does the job. Also a bit weird that Saito is just able to wipe any charges from Cobb’s record or find him in Mombasa just before he gets caught by the people chasing him (though this may or may not be a dream sequence but even then, whose mind are they in at the moment?) I may have misremembered some of this as I haven’t seen the movie in a few months but I’ve seen it 3 or 4 times; like I said it’s one of my favorites but it admittedly has some flaws that some may be put off by. Tldr great movie with occasional plot armor to keep the story going, “objectively” speaking it’s a 9/10 for me but it’s the kind of movie I really like and am probably going to enjoy a bit more than most people no matter what.

It is such a breathtaking movie, and the breathtaking moments start from the very beginning. It is a bit confusing to follow, but they do go along and explain what is happening and what "Inception" is. The big twist when we learn that Cobb had already used Inception on his wife is shocking! I don't know about your opinions, but I believe Cobb is accountable for his wife's death -- even though he didn't physically kill her, he planted a dangerous idea to "keep her safe" which backfired to her committing suicide. The whole movie is breathtaking and superbly made. It is one of the most unique/original sci-fi films out there!

Me parece que el como se explora la subjetividad de cada mundo presentado en esta película es posiblemente lo mejor de la misma. Christopher Nolan, nos regala un mundo aunque muy complejo siempre interesante. Siempre con ese sello de calidad que este director posee. Donde aunque si te distraes le puedes perder la pista a la película, la misma se encarga de dejarte el desarrollo claro en escenas explicativas. El como los personajes se desarrollan en la trama es muy interesante. Teniendo el conflicto interno de cada uno de ellos expuesto en la trama, ya que la película se apoya de ellos para llegar al punto climático de la cinta, la película se basa completamente de las emociones de los personajes; ya sea como el personaje de Leonardo Di Caprio se embarca en esta película por recuperar a sus hijos o como el personaje de Ken Watanabe se embarca en un propósito igualmente personal; La estructura de esta película se hace fuerte en la profundización de personajes. Los efectos especiales de esta película me volaron la cabeza; solo cabe ver en detrás de cámara de la escena del pasillo para notar que estamos ante una película totalmente diferente. En esta película todos los involucrados pasaron a ser los mejores de la industria, se puede notar la dedicación que se le puso a esta película, ya sea en cosas notorias como las antes mencionadas o en pequeñas sutilezas en como esta estructurado cada escenario. Esta película a pesar de tener sub tramas que no terminan de cerrar, te lleva por un mundo muy interesante. Un mundo que no te deja de sorprender en cada acto de la película. Una historia con una estructura casi perfecta. Los recuerdos negativos tienden a opacar a los recuerdos positivos.

Inception is a fantastic cinematic premise. And the special effects are some of the greatest ever seen in a movie. However, spectacular effects by themselves cannot make up for storyline or storey flaws. In addition, the storyline and tale have a number of flaws. One is the belief that companies are evil creatures vying for global dominion by snatching whatever they can from competitors. While this may be true for one or two tiny corporations, huge multinationals could never afford the negative publicity that such activities would generate, and hence it is not credible for over 99 percent of multinationals. Although DiCaprio is good, and the supporting cast gives it their all, the film falls short.

You are somehow brought among the characters and you feel their current anxiety. There are also some brilliant scenes which seem really charismatic, especially the ending when you really wonder, stare at the totem spinning, and try to understand whether this whole mission has succeeded or not. The only problem I had with this movie was unnatural occurrences, specifically the soldiers not reaching the protagonists, although there wasn't any rational inhibitor for them.

In Christopher Nolan's climactic "Inception", Dominic Hobb, an expert dream thief specializing in corporate espionage, is given the possibility to return to his family as a reward for executing the seemingly impossible task of planting an idea into someone's mind. All the while, Hobb must battle the secrets that lie beneath his own subconscious.

Honestly, I was expecting much more from this film. But it took me around 10 tries to sit through its entirety. Not only is Inception's runtime bulky, we aren't introduced to all of our key characters until around the 50-minute mark and it takes 90 minutes for the epic plan to take motion.

You kind of have to watch it with company in order to stay hooked. Your viewing buddy will have to keep you focused, because it is far too easy to get drowned in what feels like a clunky, massive information dump (in the first act). The excess exposition bogs down the pace of the story, which is so difficult to follow with all of the dreams inside of dreams inside of dreams… 

The talented cast gave sterling performances, with Gordon-Levitt being my personal favorite. The best thing about Inception's editing and cinematography is that a great deal of the visual effects were shot practically and were admittedly stunning. And while the third act is a bit drawn out, it is undeniably the best part of the film. The intercut action sequences feel a bit more cohesive. It was great to see the team in action rather than the team in talking.

To say the least, Inception is WAY overhyped, has an acquired taste, and did not exceed my expectations. In true Christopher Nolan fashion, this movie comes with an avalanche of too much exposition to stick to your brain that comes hurling at you at a snail's speed. But when it hits you, and destroys everything in sight, it's something to see… I guess. 68%.

A perfectly paced, written and directed story that will send your mind to an endless pondering and mesmerising journey. 
Nolan really knows what he's doing when it comes fiction. He knows how to deliberately lose the audience's comprehension to then retrieve it with magnificence. What truly makes Nolan's famous fiction movie Inception a masterpiece of time and reality mayhem, is the way the story is written and developed. It starts with a pretty strenuous concept: the inception of dreams. But then, as the story unwraps, with well-pace actions, embracing dialogues and great characters dissections, we begin to fathom what this concept of infiltrating dreams can serve for, alongside how it actually works – using great insight of true physics and thorough studies upon the very subject of dreams and time. All leading to an ending that wraps into this "open ways" notion. 
The casting is straight up perfect. Leonardo DiCaprio embraced the role of Dom Cobb as a professional, really diving into the trauma of the protagonist and exploiting the pain and adventurous errands that this character went through in his past. Tom Hardy nailed the role of the Eames, a character capable of impersonating others within one's dream, using his seriousness and his passionate sheer acting. Cillian Murphy, managed to play the role of a broken son left with the legacy of his dead father like a boss, using his prowess acting and his bewitching voice. And last, but not least, Eliott Page, who really knows how to do her job and create an emotional and interesting character, Ariadne, ready to help her team as the ingenious architect of dreams. 
I could spend a day writing about the story and how the cast, the full cast, is perfectly chosen, but I think the points I've given are enough to catch your attention – without spoiling the whole narrative – if you haven't seen the movie yet.

Compelling if not a bit convoluted. It takes its time in the beginning - holding itself at too high a bar if you ask me - only to finally get going at the end of the 2nd act and beginning of the 3rd. All in all, 'Inception' is still one of Nolan's better movies and deserves at least one watch - but I wouldn't blame you if you didn't.

Inception - Anatomy of Excellence

Almost everything about "Inception" is excellent !

The acting is on top by everyone in the cast. The pace of the movie is perfect.

There are some hiccups like; The character "Ariadne" who's only purpose is to answer questions which then get answered by another character. This doesn't ruin the pace of the movie but it feels like a little disconnect. Because every other character in the movie knows exactly what's going on except when they haven't been informed about the job (which then is very obvious they would have questions).

Nothing of this ruin the movie but bring it down from the "Masterpiece" title.

The meaning and understanding of the movie are though very hard to get. The whole movie has two very straight forward and simple goals : Plant the idea of splitting up Robert Fishers' father's empire which will then give Cobb safety to go home to his kids. But there is a lot more to understand about the movie (which I will not go in-depth to in this review).

The choreography is amazing. It's seem less to watch the fight-scenes. And it really looks like it would be in a dream. Writing is excellent and it awws me every time that it took around ten years to write the movie.

All of this ads up to a excellent, re-watchable movie which I would recommend to anybody !

The very first time I watched this film I made the mistake of not paying enough attention, the film lost me almost at once with its complex and intertwining storyline. However on the second viewing it really took me in and proved to me to be one of the greatest films of all time. The combined brilliance of the score by Hans Zimmer (perhaps the best score in cinema history), the directing by Christopher Nolan and the acting by the entire cast created this emotional masterpiece. It questions the very reality we live in and where we go when we dream. Scenes such as the father-son scene with Cillian Murphy are so full of emotion and the timing of each shot has you hanging on the edge of your seat in suspense. 
So I fully recommend this film to everyone although it may take a couple of viewings to truly give it justice.

I'm nearly at a loss for words. Just when you thought Christopher Nolan couldn't follow up to "The Dark Knight", he does it again, delivering another masterpiece, one with so much power and rich themes that has been lost from the box office for several years. Questioning illusions vs reality usually makes the film weird, but Nolan grips your attention like an iron claw that you just can't help watching and wondering what will happen next. That is a real powerful skill a director has. No wonder Warner Bros. put their trust in him, he is THAT good of a director, and over-hyping a Christopher Nolan film, no matter what the film is about, is always an understatement instead of an overestimate like MANY films before.

Not since the eras of Stanley Kubrick, Andrei Tarkovsky and Alfred Hitchcock has there been a more brilliant director than Christopher Nolan. He is, undoubtedly, one of THE most brilliant and gifted Hollywood filmmakers in history. Filmmakers like him come but just once in a lifetime. He has the ability to seduce our eyes, ears and most importantly, mind, and then delivers what he intends to deliver in full blast. Rarely have blockbusters have the gall to deliver such amounts imagination and intelligence at the same time. And yes, it is similar to the excellent anime film "Paprika" in the whole "invading dreams" plot, but the similarities end there as Nolan brings the film to a whole different level.

Visuals and intelligence rarely come together in movies at the same time, it's either all-visuals-no-smarts ("G.I. Joe", "Transformers") or the exact opposite ("Doubt", "Invictus"). In this film the excellently directed action sequences combined with immensely groundbreaking and jaw-dropping visual effects are combined smoothly with a heavy dose of intelligence and believability.

Although having an ensemble cast and financed by a Hollywood giant studio (Warner Bros), this film is a very personal film for Nolan, he wrote the film as well as directing it, and as you watch the film you get many glimpses of Nolan's perplexing, increasingly imaginative thoughts and dreams in the dialog that he writes and the plot that he sets up. Ideas have never felt more interesting and put to good use than in this film. This film is NOT for the popcorn muncher, rather it is a film for thinkers. Honestly I can't explain the plot for fear of spoiling the movie for you readers. Even the slightest hint will ruin the experience. The viewer will walk out of the cinema feeling dazed, confused and ultimately breathless. It's like a puzzle, both physically and mentally, and you have to pay attention throughout the film for the clues. However Nolan controls the spectacle of the film and is careful not to let it overwhelm the film's humanity, and this is where "Inception" shines. It is a very deep film that will have one thinking and asking questions for years to come. That's right, years.

Once the film ends, you'll want to watch it again, for there's something new every time. This is a film that requires multiple viewing for someone to truly comprehend the film's ambiguous themes, and will be discussed by many in the future. This is an original film, no adaptation, no sequel/prequel, no remake/reboot, which is extremely refreshing having gone nearly three years of mostly unremarkable visual effects roadshows ("Avatar" be damned).

Of course, a film is not complete without the actors. Leo DiCaprio delivers an Oscar worthy performance, similar but better than his previous effort "Shutter Island". He shows glimpses of a flawed, grim, fragile man, who has knowledge about everything else but yet can't seem to come in grips with himself and his demons. Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe, Dileep Rao, Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger, Michael Caine, Marion Cottilard, Pete Postlethwaite, Lukas Haas... Nolan really brings out the best in this unusual yet extremely talented group of supporting actors who make their roles their own.

Nolan is of course, a master behind the camera, a real virtuoso when it comes to film. His direction is taut, focused, gripping, and extraordinarily fascinating. The detailed and complex original script is no surprise from Nolan, considering the fact that he turned Batman the superhero into pop-culture art two years ago ("The Dark Knight"). The action sequences are unique, exciting and fresh, something absent from the cinema which has since been interested at things popping towards the screen and stuff blowing up every two milliseconds. The visual effects are awesome and imaginative, and best of all they do not bring down the movie's quality one bit, rather it makes the movie more fascinating to watch. The cinematography is absolutely, beautifully shot, so we can see the action and emotion in all their glory. Production design is top notch, with terrific design of sets and locations. Hans Zimmer's complementing music score is simply outstanding, and knowing the man, that's really all I have to say. Together all of these elements combine to deliver a mesmerizing movie experience like no other this year.

Christopher Nolan has once again outdone himself. He truly is a gifted filmmaker, arguably the most imaginative in Hollywood today. And "Inception" can proudly stand alongside "Blade Runner" and "2001: A Space Odyssey" as science-fiction masterpieces that push the boundaries for movie making and become a different experience altogether.

There are two types of films: the crowd-pleasing blockbuster and the intelligent indie/art film. Nolan has combined two of these tropes together into one exceptionally brilliant package, pulling off that rare, now nearly-extinct Movie Magic that has since been wiped off the planet by sequelitis and reboots. Movie of Summer 2010? Movie of 2010? Heck this is possibly the first masterpiece of the decade! Nolan is a genius and I applaud him for treating his audiences as intelligent people.

Inception - 10/10. If Memento introduced the world to Christopher Nolan, and The Dark Knight elevated his career to becoming one of the biggest directors, then Inception catapulted Nolan into a league of his own. Inception has become everyones favourite "confusing" film (to be honest, the movie is pretty straightforward if you pay your full attention towards it). The film, which was being promoted as an action thriller, was so much more than that. There was the iconic action sequences of course, but there also was an amazing emotional quotient to the film. The film is also pretty interesting to think about, because technically Leonardo DiCaprio's Don Cobb could be considered the bad guy as he alters the thought process of Cillian Murphy's businessman character in order to allow Ken Watanabe to succeed in his ventures. Also, the movie doesn't have a direct antagonist if you think about it. Watanabe and Marion Cotillard are presented as possible villains, but they're not necessarily evil incarnate. Both have specific motives which are not specifically evil. Cotillard's character in particular is very layered, and we see that even though we as the viewer might see her as a villain, she has Cobb as a reason why she acts and thinks the way she does. But what Nolan made possible with Inception was one thing in particular, "smart blockbuster." He helped prove to studios that creating a huge movie with incredible depth could be financially and critically successful. Not only have directors and studios over the years referenced or tried to make the next Inception type film, but we've also seen these big films try to make spectacle work in throwback ways. Like the majority of his films, most of the big stuff was done on set and in camera, allowing the viewer to really sense how real the production values are. But the biggest success of this movie is probably the fact it is still being talked about to this day. Some movies are forgotten within months, but Inception has been a talking point for cinema goers for years now. And the answer to the final scene: Cobb is in reality. Not only is not wearing his ring, but the top never wobbles in the dream.

It's not a cinematic masterpiece, but it also isn't garbage.  The thinking and concept behind it is really neat, I just think they goofed up on a couple of fronts in terms of casting and dialogue. And now I have literally no idea what he was smoking. This movie is a masterpiece even by Hollywood standards. It will continue to be known as an iconic movie for generations to come.

The story is based on Cobb, a thief who uses people's dreams to to learn about their secrets and then uses them to steal from them. Because of the movie's title I thought that the entire movie is taking place in a dream and when they are actually shown to go in a dream it is supposed to be an inception. It was only after I read about it on Wikipedia that I understood that the main movie is taking place outside of dreams.

Christopher Nolan did the absolute right thing by using practical effects instead of CGI. And it was also a pretty genius move to show your dreams that can actually happen in reality. Although many of the dreams shown in the movie look more like James bond films instead of actual dreams, I wouldn't just on that perspective since this is a subjective idea. Most probably many people have such kinds of dreams and they were the ones who were kept in mind when writing the story. But overall this was a great idea since the whole idea is that Cobb steals from the dreams of people and they would not realise that it is a dream only if it is made to be shown as realistic as possible.

The characters have also been explored very well. Cobb's wife used to be his partner in crime, but after a while she got so much addicted to the inception machine that she started thinking that the real life is also a dream and thus she committed suicide thinking that she will be able to meet cob in his real life. Cobb has been holding himself responsible for his wife's death and does wants a chance to correct his mistake. He has recruited a college student learning architecture and that provides a good way to give exposition without making it look either forced or confusing.

The only problem I had with this movie was the amount of talking that happens. In every scene there is talking, talking and even more talking, whether it is the the real world scenes or the dreamscapes. It was really boring to see them talk in a movie that is supposed to be about going into other people's dreams and stealing their knowledge and memories. The amount of exposition also seemed unnecessary and it felt like it was only meant to explain the people who are very slow to understand. But other than that I didn't have any problem.

Overall I would say that Inception is one of those movies which define the decade as well as the the potential of Christopher Nolan's storytelling. This movie is a perfect blend of looking legendary and having mostly used practical effects. I considered to be the best Christopher Nolan movie after The Dark Knight.

without spoilers I want to make you understand a bit of what it's about; is an action and thriller film, lasting 2 hours and 28 minutes. Talks about Dominic Cobb is a professional who takes care of extracting secrets from people's minds while they sleep, infiltrating their dreams through a special device that allows a group to participate in a "shared dream".  Cobb and his team normally use tricks and deceptions to steal information from the victim, who he believes to be in reality and suspects nothing.  Together with his partner Arthur tries to enter the mind of Mr. Saito, a powerful Japanese businessman, to perform an extraction, but fails when the dream projection of Mal, dead wife of Cobb, appears in the dream interfering with the  operation.
I advise you to look at it very carefully, otherwise, you will not understand the ending well.

Inception is really well done, and they merged a lot of weird material into a single, somewhat cohesive film.  Strong on visuals and weirdness.  I admit, it made more sense watching it the second time.  I have some minor issues with the film - why do we dream in fractals?  Why are the dreams always synced?  Why do we dream 'faster'? etc.. but those things are kind of marginal to the plot as it rips along.  If I had a major quibble, I guess I am not really sure who the 'good guys' are here, and Leonardo, while a competent actor, is not likeable.  But then, maybe that is what they were going for here.

Rewatch this adventure from my favorite director Nolan. The first time that I watched it, which was long ago, I remembered not getting the full story, so I didn't think it was a masterpiece, although I did like it. However, this time was quite different. 

I was hooked right away within the opening scene, which showed the dream within a dream sequence that introduced the premise very well. Then, as the characters showed more about the movie's universe, I was so amazed with the cinematography, like the scene where the dream world was flip into half up and down. 

The story itself was complicated and required me to stay focused. Since I got some memories of when I first watched the movie, I did not struggle too much to fully grasp what was going on. This was for sure not as complicated as Tenet. 

With the story, Nolan dived into the human subconscious and applied the Freudian psychology. 

Overall, a total blast for the whole 2.5 hours. This is definitely one of Nolan's best masterpieces. 9.5/10
Wonderful, it kept me thrilled until the end.  I cannot even convey the amount of time that I spent speculating about the ending.  Absolute MUST SEE.

This is one of the best cinematic viewing experiences that has ever been made and will likely remain so for the rest of human history. The level of complexity in the plot, the attention to detail, the clear and wise cinematography choices with differing color palettes and excellent camera angles, and the sheer ambition to pull off a film of this magnitude are all breathtaking and leave me with a sense of reverence for Nolan. The issue I had was that he went out of his way to introduce elements to make the team's path to success more difficult but did so in an unfortunate way, having his main character thoughtlessly insist on imperiling the mission when plenty of alternatives existed for relaying to Eames the shortcut and explaining away the added danger of sedation by basically making it a magical sedative that only leaves you in mortal danger within the dream but will still let you wake up if kicked. Surely with some proofreading or outside notes these could've been handled more carefully and we would've been left with an absolute timeless masterpiece. Alas, we are left with only a fantastically good movie instead.

If you're looking for a satisfying action thriller, this is definitely for you. It can be a little difficult to understand on the first viewing, but believe me, it's very much worth the little extra brainpower spent looking at it.

In a world where anything is possible nothing is surprising. Thus this movie is a compete bore. 
One ad hoc twist after another explained away by the fact that people can, not only enter each others dreams, but can add to the dream's content as well. 
Then, of course, someone in a dream can go to sleep and create another dream level. 
When someone gets killed in a dream they wake up into the next higher level. But for some reason another twist is added whereby the dreamer sometimes does not wake up but ends up trapped in a place called ‘limbo'. Don't ask me why. 
Of course, after a while you lose track of the dreams and their levels. 
If you can stand all this then go ahead and see    the movie. I myself did not find one minute interesting.

My first and favorite Nolan film, Inception is a beautifully shot, cerebral masterpiece. The concept itself is interesting enough to deserve its own franchise, but Inception keeps the plot tight enough to tell an exciting, dramatic, action-packed story. The special effects have aged wonderfully and the cinematography is impressive and intentional - each level of the final dream sequence has its own color scheme and uniquities which helped to keep the story clear and concise.

On my first viewing, I felt like this movie was far more clever than I was, constantly twisting and turning and keeping some secrets stashed for just the right moment. However, on a subsequent viewing, I realized the plot isn't quite as neat as I originally thought - there are a few points that are never really addressed, along with some plot holes and general glossings-over. Inception does a good job at keeping the disbelief suspended with its engaging performances and impressive set pieces, but it ultimately could have been a little better within even just a hand-waving explanation of some of the more obvious contradictions.

Though it's a bit overcomplicated and not the strongest with characters, Inception is a dazzling movie. Its premise and budget allows director Christopher Nolan to portray some of the most unforgettably mind-bending ideas ever put to film.

Inception is a movie from 2010 about a father, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, trying to get home to his kids. To do that he needs to do one last very risky job where he will enter someone's unconscious mind while they're asleep and try to plant an idea in their mind. The problem he has with that is that by entering there he also goes down into his own unconsciousness and it'll bring his dead wife into his mission accidentally, who will become a problem for everyone involved. It finishes with him finally getting home but right before the end there's a huge hint pointing out that he may still be asleep and being home is just another level to his unconscious desires which would mean he never really got home nor is he living his real life anymore.

I wholeheartedly love this movie. The ideas of exploring one's unconscious and the way of distorting time the director plays with throughout the movie are just amazing to me. There's a lot of explanation as to how dreams work and the roles your mind plays in each level of your dreams, and the director put so much in blurring the lines between reality and dreams so artistically that it inevitably feels like watching a moving masterpiece. There is a scene in which DiCaprio is talking to someone in a bar and the building he is in starts to shake because the characters are in a car chase in the previous level of unconsciousness. It is obviously a science fiction movie, but it is explained in such a perfect way that it is as believable as it is nerve wrecking and intriguing. At the beginning you can see how different people work and get trained for the job, learning to manipulate one's mind. I think just the concept of the movie is so interesting, I'd watch it all the time, however there's more than just that. The music and sound effects are just as good and accompany the vibe of the movie incredibly. Every single detail was clearly thoroughly thought about and adds to the realism of the movie in the most astonishing way. 

In my opinion, the only thing that is missing from this movie is character "personality", the characters are not really individually introduced and most of them don't have any kind of development through the movie but I think, if anything, that allows the viewers to concentrate more on what they do rather than who they are or why they act a certain way. The director probably put less attention on the characters to put the emphasis on the visuals of the movie, which only makes it even more captivating. Essentially, I don't think there's anything in this movie, present or missing, that wasn't done on purpose.

In conclusion, the movie Inception by Christopher Nolan can be simply described as a masterpiece and I would highly recommend it to anyone. I believe every part of it was deliberately and meticulously calculated. It is so well structured that it keeps you hanging on the edge of your seat the whole time while deeply going into detail about what is happening. The movie has no plot holes, in my opinion, and it just still leaves your head spinning for answers and processing everything you just watched with an amazing suspense type of ending.
One of the greatest movies ever. Satisfying intellectually & emotionally, as well as an epic action/espionage/sci-fi movie, not to mention it's bold originality.

This is Christopher Nolan's magnum opus and it is also one of my favorite movies ever made. Every actor gives incredible performances with such great chemistry with Leonardo standing out as usual, the visual effects are absolutely incredible with a great combination of sets, practical effects and CGI and this leads to some truly incredible action like the opening scene, the rotating hallway fight and the fight on the snowy mountain. The story is incredibly intriguing and creative with so much worldbuilding and the movie explains the rules of this world very well in a way that doesn't talk to its audience. The audience needs to actually pay attention to what's going on and I love that. It actually makes you think and the story leads to an incredibly exciting last 75 minutes as you genuinely feel scared for the characters, not just because they almost lose but the first hour sets up how important the mission super well but at its core, it's a character-driven story about a man wanting to see his children again and getting over the loss of his wife and seeing Cobb open up to Ariadne about what has happened and her helping him get over it is quite emotional. And how can I forget Hans Zimmer's incredible score? One of the best movies ever made and a must-watch.

THE ONE THING that disappoints the most about this film is that, even though the film transpires mostly in people's dreams, there is very little that is dreamlike about them. Instead, the dream landscapes are there to accommodate a handful of action movie setpieces. They are visually stunning setpieces to be sure. In particular, the gravity defying fight scene in a hotel corridor, in which people's bodies are pulled toward constantly shifting centers of gravity, to match a parallel tumble off a bridge in which the bodies of the sleeping dreamers within the dream are plummeting through space in a van. It is a remarkable achievement. However, it is not the stuff of dreams. Dreams are eery and psychologically unsettling. They express buried fears and longings while hinting at the existence of awe-inspiring supernatural forces. And quite often, the locations are spare and minimal. Great filmmakers like Federico Fellini and David Lynch filmed dream sequences that left viewers with gooseflesh, and they did so by fiddling with combinations of settings and sounds usually in spare surroundings. They did so by tugging at the viewer's empathic sense of kinship with the character, and sparking a commingled sense of attraction and dread to the dream narrative. Films can only achieve this effect of heightened emotion and involvement when there is something at stake, something that the viewer cares about. Regrettably, I didn't care about anybody or any outcome in Inception. Will one multinational corporation surpass the other in wealth? Who cares? Will the morally shady Dominic be reunited with his kids? I don't care that much because he's an emotionally closed character. Will Christopher Nolan tie up all the loose ends in his high tech mental thriller? I suppose he did but, again, I didn't care.
     Inception reminds me of another film in which the main character yearns to return home, The Wizard of Oz. But unlike that film, it is all brains and no heart. Nolan needs to find the courage to admit he is wanting as a complete filmmaker and change his game to reflect the maxim that I learned when I entered teacher's college: "No one cares how much you know until they know how much you care."

Inception is a brilliant movie and its's honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a brilliant story and it's about this lad called Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) who steals important information from his targets, the way he does it is by entering their dreams and getting the main information he's after.

However, a lad who's called Saito (Ken Watanabe) offers to get rid of Cobb's complete criminal history record as a payment for performing an inception on his sick contender's son.

The movie's got some brilliant performance's from each character throughout this movie, especially from Leonardo DiCaprio. I thought he gave one of his greatest performances throughout this movie, he shows his emotions really well and he plays the role of the main character so good.

The dialogue which is given from each character throughout this movie is very strong, while non of the dialogue which is given or received feels weak in any sort of way.

Also, the humour which is scattered throughout this movie works really well and it always hits and it never misses in making me laugh in some sort of way.

The pacing throughout this movie is all honestly great, all of the build ups to certain scenes which end up happening throughout this movie are all built up very well.

The movie's even got some very beautiful visual effects, which actually hold up very well due to this movie coming out in 2010 and they don't look very dated at all, which I think is another positive for this movie.

Finally, the movie's cinematography which was done by Wally Pfister is honestly so beautiful, he did such a great job on capturing the moments so well and making them look so great. I'm so happy that he got quite a few awards for the best cinematography in 2010, he honestly deserves them he did such a great job.

The action sequences which end up happening throughout this movie, either it being in the real world or the dream world are all very well done and they're also very cleverly done, which I thought was really good.

The score which was composed by Hans Zimmer is honestly really well done and I think he did such a great job on composing the full soundtrack for this movie.

Overall, Inception is a brilliant movie and it's honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a brilliant story, brilliant performances, strong dialogue, great humour, great pacing, beautiful visual effects, beautiful cinematography, very clever action sequences and a great score which was composed by the man, the myth and the legend Hans Zimmer.

This movie is honestly worth the watch, I'd recommend everyone to watch this, you'll probably enjoy it quite a bit.

This is my favorite movie of all time. Maybe soon this will change, but for right now it tops my list. I love this movie because of how much deals with. The layers of this movie make it what it is. Some could say this is all about family and what family can do to the mind. Others can say that this is just a big analogy of movie production. What tops all is how this movie can pick apart a mind in such a casual manner. A beautiful used this idea as the main idea for the movie, whereas Nolan uses this idea and combines it with action, romance, and grief. Nolan is at his best with his direction. The movie is shot beautifully and he's never been better in the action department because in his Dark Knight Trilogy the action is shot very poorly. In this, he uses firearms instead of hand to hand and he doesn't use a ton of cuts. Also, the scene where the ground shifts is so well shot. His camera tricks in that scene are so smart and unique. Not only that the movie is written to perfection, but it's also very well thawed out and clearly looks like it went through at least a hundred drafts. The performances are also spectacular. Dicaprio is amazing and Tom Hardy adds some very well placed charisma. Lastly, Ellen Page was more than up for the job as the opposite lead to Dicaprio and she is the perfect way to gently put in the much-needed exposition. Without Page's character, the movie would be a mess. I give Inception a 100%.

There should be a disclaimer at the beginning of this movie that warns you to pay close attention and not go out for popcorn in the middle of the movie, or else you will never fully appreciate the intricacies of the movie.  Even with such a warning, it is probably best enjoyed during a subsequent viewing, allowing you to digest what you originally saw.  The biggest problem with this movie is that, in an attempt to maintain its action/thriller label, the intricately created psychological construct at the heart of the movie gets lost among the bullets and constantly changing dream levels.  The true enjoyment of the movie does not come during the original viewing, but during the subsequent contemplation, and ultimate understanding, of the true message behind the madness.

For me, this is one of those movies that changes everything. This isn't the first time I've watched Inception, but every time I do, I bring a top out and spin it just to be sure I'm not dreaming. Upon, I think my fourth watch, it's safe to say that I understand so much more of this movie than I did my first watch. Having a movie that requires multiple watches is always good, honestly, I'm not sure how I missed certain moments of this. But, making a mystery this good is already a huge bonus here. I'm going to sound like a broken record player when I say this, but Christopher Nolan is changing Blockbusters almost as much as Steven Spielberg back in the days of Jaws. Rather than focusing on a previously established franchise (excluding the Dark Knight Trilogy), he finds an original idea and makes an amazing film out of it. These films don't only have the fast paced moments to keep casual viewers entertained, but also some quieter moments making the story and characters feel rich, making the world feel that it is lived in. With Inception, Nolan takes the concept of going inside dreams and makes it into a heist movie. That wouldn't work if it weren't for some of the amazing settings of this movie, some of which were filmed on location. While I would never have a dream as down to earth as any of the dreams in Inception, I'm glad Christopher Nolan made the choice to use settings that are quite normal, this way there is always that small voice in the back of your head questioning whether the characters are dreaming or not. There is plenty of symbolism in this movie to richen the mystery as well. The character of Cobb's father is seemingly a large clue pointing to what's real. Even some of the action feels well paced. Note that I say some. As, unfortunately, most of the action in this movie ends up in the final act, which is common, but the way that any threat to the characters is immediately diffused doesn't really work for me. While the reveals at the end put everything into place in one's head, all the emotional moments at the end are crammed in next to action scenes, many of which I couldn't tell what was happening. Inception is a brilliant film. In typical Nolan style, he makes a big budget blockbuster that has A-list stars, but doesn't get too caught up in what the studio wants so it can make money, he made the Dark Knight trilogy, he's going to make money. Christopher Nolan knows how to make his movies meaningful to everyone, and seeing this just makes me more excited for Tenet.

Inception has a great and very thrilling premise and benefits from great actors in the leading roles. Looking into it, the general premise and the ideas of extraction and inception are pretty well fleshed out and explained. However, there are two main issues: The inconsistencies (such as regarding the effect of the kicks or the exact situation in limbo) and the fact that a lot of backstory has to constantly be explained. The latter was clearly tried to be made nicer by introducing the character Ariadne and as a newcomer having her learn everything. This is generally a good idea but all of the background surrounding Cobb combined with the specifics of dreams just mean that we are constantly being told information instead of seeing it happen. However, despite this, it is a solid story with a good plot twist / open ending, a great cast and an amazing score. Plus, it has a huge amount of rewatching potential.

Christopher Nolan directs his sci-fi thriller Inception (2010) with a keen eye, creative mind, vast potential, and astute precision. Inception is sleek thanks to Christopher Nolan's inventive direction and original script. Inception is famous for its shocking twists, breathtaking cinematography, and high concept narrative. Nolan's ambitious direction ends you stunning you with strange and enticing visuals, enthralling action sequences, and groundbreaking visual effects. The CGI holds up as cities fold unto themselves and worlds collapse, while I also appreciate Nolan's dedication to practical effects like the revolving hotel hallway fight that's already as iconic as it is impressive. Inception is mind boggling due to Nolan's creative directorial vision and unique focused auteur style. No other director could have crafted Inception.

Leonardo DiCaprio is heartbreaking and enthralling as the lead Dom Cobb. His mind robber is so cool and in control until his past tears at his heart. DiCaprio is devastating during a particular hotel room scene on a balcony. Marion Cotillard delivers her greatest acting in Inception as Mal Cobb. Her chemistry is apparent with DiCaprio. She sweeps you off your feet with surprise appearances, sultry looks, and seductive words, but Cotillard uses her warm eyes and sincere voice to command your attention. Together, DiCaprio and Cotillard elevate an already magnificent film into an instant classic.

Joseph Gordon-Levitt is too cool as the operator of the mind breaching equipment. Inception remains some of his best acting that I like more every time I watch him here. Ellen Page is astounding as Ariadne the architect of the dream worlds. Her mind is sharp as are her comebacks as DiCaprio's foil, but it is Page's empathy for the suffering of others in Inception that makes her character so sympathetic and likable. Ellen Page has never acted better than within the tender affection she portrays in Inception.

Tom Hardy is hilarious as Zak Eames. He's just effortless in Inception. Ken Watanabe is so smooth and captivating in Inception as Mr. Saito. I do not want to spoil a single moment of his revelation of a performance. Cillian Murphy is fun to watch him get duped in Inception as Robert Fischer, but his final farewell to his father, played by a phenomenal Pete Postlethwaite, is just soul crushing to see.

Michael Caine is astute and poignant as Stephen Miles in a great scene as DiCaprio's foil. Dileep Rao is funny as Yusuf. Tom Berenger is excellent and particular as Peter Browning. Lukas Haas has an interesting cameo as Nash the architect. Keep an eye out for the flight attendant as that's Christopher Nolan's cousin Miranda Nolan! Lastly, Talulah Riley is gorgeous and alluring in her cameo as The Blonde.

Christopher Nolan's original script demonstrates his writing prowess at creating an imaginative science fiction story centered around a mental heist to insert an idea into someone's head. His intricate plot of diving deeper into layers of dreams within dreams once confused me, but upon revisiting Inception, I actually understood the entire plot because Nolan goes out of his way to include you by indoctrinating you into this chaotic world through his informative dialogue and perceptive nuance. His ideas are ambitious and unique with intelligent thoughtfulness, but always accessible to the audience through his pristine style and common language. Inception is incredibly well written down to every clever line. I have to mention Nolan's heartfelt themes and inclusion of emotional connections to engage the viewer despite their certain confusion. Inserting a father and son's bond with a husband and wife's estrangement is genius levels of depth on top of all the dream diving. The start washing into the end's shoreline is just too smart.

Lee Smith's editing is mind numbing to think about how he spliced together the exact order of each dream level sequence. Nolan and him must have talked for hours about Inception's sequencing and editing style. Wally Pfister's cinematography is sleek and striking with some of cinema's most iconic shots: the city folding on top of itself, the mirrors reframing the shot, stairs appearing out of nowhere, to the gorgeous shorelines of consciousness in Limbo. So many lovely wide shots envelop Inception's cold methodical world in a sense of wonder. The production design makes everything look sterile and crisp, so that anything can appear suddenly and look natural.

Hans Zimmer's legendary score for Inception is infamous for his blaring bursts of sound and beloved for his epic scope of sonic noise. Zimmer composed some of his best material for a gripping score to accompany Inception's captivating action. The costumes and make-up look like a Tom Ford or Gucci commercial, they are that clean cut and slimming. You can count all the cool suits. Marion Cotillard's dresses are simply sublime on her.

In all, Inception is an all time great film of astounding originality and creative filmmaking. Christopher Nolan clearly wanted to outdo himself and he ended up directing one of his best features with Inception.

"Inception" is Christopher Nolan's science fiction drama, released in 2010 and that grossed more than $800 million worldwide (film is definitely successful, because the budget is $160 million).
Christopher Nolan is creaing this art perfomance as a director, screenwriter and one of the producers.
Operator - Wally Pfister
Composer - Hans Zimmer
Artists: Guy Diaz, Luke Freeborn, Brad Ricoeur
   The main character Cobb is a unique thief: he steals valuable secrets from the depths of the subconscious during sleep, when the human mind is most vulnerable. Cobb's abilities and capabilities made him a valuable player in the world of espionage, but they also turned him into an eternal fugitive and deprived him of his family.
And now Cobb has a chance to correct mistakes. He, along with his team, will have to implement the idea, and not steal it.
   I'll start with the cons.
Firstly, the visualization is messy. The characters of the picture are engaged in espionage, penetrating the dreams of their victims. Does that actually look as a dream? Not. Rather, there are continuous labyrinths of surrealism and empty absurdity. For example, cool concept of the Cobb's subconscious multi-level world could be made more spectacular.
Secondly, in fact, "Inception" is mainly an action movie of the 21st century, that attempts to also include drama and look thought-provoking.
Thirdly, not a single character is perfomed enough, and the script line with the wife of the protagonist looks dull. As a viewer, I was completely uninterested in Cobb's experiences and his relationship with his wife.
Further, druing the film, the feeling that "now, it will definitely begin!" doesn't leave you. But nothing begins. There is no goddamn madness.
In this chaotic hurricane, not a damn thing is clear. And he makes the pathos public exaggerate the meaning of the "Inception" and include it in all kinds of movie tops for all time, and to justify saying that this movie is not for everyone.
Passing through pros, the main plus in the film is music. Hans Zimmer's music fits the "drama" of the film.
The second plus is imagination - the integration of ideas through sleep and so on will excite any viewer, because it is original and unusual. Nolan even developed a whole concept - the creation of sleep, a sense of time. But it turned out far-fetched.

This is one of those movies that I had always meant to go see, but never got around to it until I finally saw it on Netflix. After watching it, I wish I had seen it before; with such a convoluted plot that at times I forgot what level the characters were even in. The level of complexity that the writers had to develop to create such a convincing world is what really drew me into the movie as one of the things that I love most in any work of fiction is understanding the world its set in. Therefore one of my big requirements for a good movie is great worldbuilding, something Inception did both literally and figuratively by not outright revealing too many details but still giving us enough to go on the establish a clear idea of the world we are witnessing. Because of that level of development I would definitely call this one of the best and most well developed plotlines I've ever seen/read.

Christopher Nolan has become a victim of overhype in my eyes as it is a shame that a perfectly fine director of semi-intellectual popcorn movies was raised to the status of a modern day Stanley Kubrick in the view of internet fan boys. In part because of all this raving that I can't help but feel slightly disappointed when I watch The Dark Knight (2008) and find another silly superhero film dressed up as a pseudo-intellectual story about guilt and fear. This film too suffers from presenting itself as high minded and intellectual when it's best moments come from the technical mastery of Nolan. He has always struggled to develop compelling characters and make the audience care about the relationships between them and this is largely what causes this film to be a passable but fairly forgettable psychological action thriller.

Dom Cobb, Leonardo DiCaprio, is traumatized by the suicide of his wife Mal, Marion Cotillard, who complicates his professional life as when he is attempting to insert thoughts into people's subconscious she interrupts his thoughts and he becomes distracted. He is hired by Japanese businessman Mr. Saito, Ken Watanabe, to convince the son of his business rival Robert Fischer, Cillian Murphy, to dismantle his business. He puts together a team to carry out this mission and the inquisitive young Ariadne, Ellen Page, probes him for information on his past and the reason that his ex-wife keeps appearing while he is attempting to plant ideas in the minds of others. When the group he has assembled become trapped in the subconscious of Fischer they realize that they must use their ingenuity and smarts to achieve their goal while also making it out alive. Meanwhile Cobb comes to terms with the decision that his wife made, partly caused by his placing ideas in her mind, and chooses to return to happiness in any form.

In today's environment of superhero films almost every movie has dazzling visuals with incredible special effects and mind-bending visuals so it is hard to cite visuals as the reason to see a film. Yes, it is exciting to see cityscapes brought towards us at an alarming rate and then to witness Page, with her tiny frame, mount this vertical street but there is the feeling that it is lacking. With all of the obvious visual homages to Kubrick it also lets itself down as the baroque style room that Fischer farewells his dying father in resembles the room seen in 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) but we can't help wanting the deep themes of that film instead of a disinteresting plot about a volatile couple. I needed more from this film and I didn't receive it which was frustrating because I began watching the film with such high hopes and that there were points where the film came close to them made it all the more maddening.

Nolan's inability to present emotionally developed or engaging characters and relationships hampers him seriously as a writer and filmmaker and that this film dedicates a significant portion of it's running time to a relationship that fails to engage hurts it. We know very little about Mal and she comes across as icy but emotionally volatile, as many women are, but she seems more like a plot device than a real character and her sudden emotional outburst are unexplained with an actress as fine as Cotillard failing to carry them off. Even seeing the children that Cobb and Mal abandons fails to elicit sympathy as we feel nothing for either of the parents and know virtually nothing about these children that would make us care for them. The end of the film wants to be profound as we understand that our protagonist wants his family so much that he is willing to accept living in an illusion in order to be with them but because we do not know Cobb and his emotional turmoil and Mal very obviously exists to propel the plot forward I was not emotionally moved at all.

Other irritations were brought on by the writing of the film as the other female character in the film, Ariadne, exists to ask the male characters around her questions about the process of ‘inception' and then have them explain to her and the audience the various plot mechanics. I wish that more had been done to flesh out these characters and perhaps with a bit more work the film would have been the intelligent popcorn film that it was hailed as.

Inception

Nolan is a filmmaker to be afraid of. What P.T. Anderson did for straight three hours in Magnolia, you are going to have that same exhausting experience in this visual galore. Inception deals with a metaphor heist commanded by an expert extractor named Cobb whose only dream is to go home. Away from the action and the skills he masters at, and in order to reach home, he goes through the final test by embracing and learning the first thought entering his mind.

I remember I was ahead of Nolan- or so I thought. I claimed to know his method of decoding a subject and then he coded this cinematic marvel in front of me. So here's how he goes through a script. He treats them like a sketch show. Simple as that. And just like in a sketch show there are plenty of sketches- duh!- surfing around it. Now, a sketch is actually a double edged sword. In the sense that it needs a start, a middle act and a final act, in every three minutes. And once you get over it- which is usually engaging for its compactness- you have to come up with an entire new idea. But this is why it favours majorly on Nolan's side. Since, he has to deal with the same world, he creates, celebrates and destroys the world in each act that also contributes to the bigger picture completing the circle and leaving us satisfied. Another thing to note here is, how he celebrates. In an "action" espionage thriller, you would expect some punches and bullets and explosives. But the way he celebrates- or in layman terms exaggerate or gloats- is by envisioning his germ of the idea on different set pieces and locations. Ergo, his action is never your typical luxurious action. Just watch Joseph Gorden Lewitt surviving on that hotel without or under influenced gravity.

Science over emotions. Yes, I think as much as brilliant the subconscious play and the contingent unknown backup plans work on the film, I found myself cheated on the emotional background that our protagonist Cobb, played remorsefully by Leonardo DiCaprio, goes through. Don't get me wrong, the back story is incredibly rich, it's just the way it is treated. It is like after every- thrice to be precise- major event, Ellen Page and DiCaprio are told to reveal little by little information about the past in order to manipulate us. But this is just a minor flaw in this Nolan's masterpiece that not only subjugates but even belittles writers like us.

Inception could honestly be considered a modern classic. It is a shame that DiCaprio didn't get as much recognition as deserved for this movie because he really did do a fantastic job. The supporting cast is very, very strong as well, this includes Molly which as a character makes the movie even more engaging. The premise is super unique and makes for an extremely interesting and different action movie experience. As a movie, it plays out similar to a heist film but with no actual heist and a much more complex plot.. Thanks to the dreaming concept, there are some points of special effects that are actually done really well and look/fit perfectly. This also applies to the well-timed speed changes, going from regular speed to slow-motion without feeling at all out of place. It is paced well and hits every beat that it tries to hit. Even if you don't particularly like the idea or genre of the film itself, I feel that it is a movie that everyone should see at some point as a representation of well-made film that takes advantage of modern effects without using them overwhelmingly.

The best things about Cristopher Nolan's "Inception" are the idea and the music. The idea is that people are able to share dreams, and to have dreams within dreams, if they have the right equipment and know what they're doing. They can even plant ideas in other people's minds through a difficult and delicate process called "inception" (as opposed to the more usual and much easier "extraction," which involves stealing thoughts from others). What makes the movie so interesting is that the "mark," or the person the inception team is targeting, doesn't know he's dreaming. Yeah, that's pretty cool. 

The movie never explains how inception works--the tech guy just flips open a silver briefcase and hooks people up with wires. And the whole idea of multiple dreams-within-dreams doesn't seem too plausible. But I was willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of the movie. (If you could believe that machines used humans for batteries in "The Matrix," you shouldn't have any trouble believing the premise here.)

The music, also by Nolan, is pulsating and effectively used, constantly driving the tension and providing much of the movie's energy. 

In the end, however, Inception is just a series of inter-spliced action scenes, some of which are preposterous. Only the music, and the fact that we keep being awed that these are all dreams within dreams, make any of it the least bit interesting.

The real problem with the film is that it's not about anything important. Well, Leonardo's character and the story about his wife are important on a personal level, but the plot surrounding the movie's act of inception by DiCaprio's team holds no interest for us. Who cares if some rich guy breaks up his father's business empire? Who cares what cartel controls the oil market? It's just not important, and the movie doesn't even try to convince us that it is. Instead, the majority of screen time is devoted to implausible car chases and fights all the way down through the dream levels. The penultimate dream level, which takes place on a snowy mountain, has one guy defeating an army of enemy agents, with the whole thing looking a lot more like a battle against inept Storm Troopers from "The Empire Strikes Back" than Nolan probably intended.

Why couldn't Nolan have made a movie about saving the world, or at least some small part of it? Then I might have cared about the outcome. But no, our hero just wants to get home by helping a foreign oil baron.

And the bit at the end that has everyone watching the movie 20 times looking for clues? That strikes me as nothing more than a simple editing trick to leave us with some ambiguity. It makes the movie seem a lot cleverer than it really is.

There was a lot to like about Inception, and it's fun to watch. The directing, acting, music, production, cinematography, and pace are all excellent, and the idea of controlling others' dreams is mind-bending. DeCaprio's storyline, which is really what the movie wants to be about, is good too. Unfortunately, it's all wrapped in nonsense that isn't worth trying to unravel.

I don't mind suspending disbelief for a work of fantasy, which this movie is.  But, I demand that the story be consistent with its premise.  A central element of the Inception story fails this test.  Mal, an experienced dreamer, knows that the dream worlds are malleable.  Yet the story would have us believe that she would fail to recognize the one state that is not so malleable - the state of woke reality.  This flaw broke the central premise of the movie for me.  It also didn't help that the story offered no reason to be invested in the scheme of the industrialist bankrolling the project.

Inception is directed and written by Christopher Nolan, and starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Tom Hardy.

The movie is about a thief who possesses the power to enter into the dreams of others. Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) doesn't steal things, he steals ideas. By projecting himself deep into the subconscious of his targets, he can glean information that even the best computer hackers can't get to. In the world of corporate espionage, Cobb is the ultimate weapon. But even weapons have their weakness, and when Cobb loses everything, he's forced to embark on one final mission in a desperate quest for redemption. This time, Cobb won't be harvesting an idea, but sowing one. Should he and his team of specialists succeed, they will have discovered a new frontier in the art of psychic espionage. They've planned everything to perfection, and they have all the tools to get the job done. Their mission is complicated, however, by the sudden appearance of a malevolent foe that seems to know exactly what they're up to, and precisely how to stop them.

The performances also are talented, everyone was more than amazing, I was amazed of how they were acting! Also the CGI, it was pretty amazing, it was sinless, actually everything about this movie is sinless.. anyways... The soundtrack by Hans Zimmer, what can I say? Stunning, I.. loved.. it!! And now, the direction, every shot was well-directed, the direction really really was amazing, Christopher Nolan is my favorite director of all the time.. actually, this movie contain lots of my favorite stuff: favorite director (Christopher Nolan), favorite composer (Hans Zimmer) and my favorite actor (Tom Hardy).

The plot didn't explain too much to keep you excited and hype, also it didn't set up the characters cause they will be explained later on, and I meant to say "explained" because these characters are super-complex. After the plot the movie took a great twist with the first act by being  little pit clear, you think? Inception is a Sci-Fi, Action-adventure film written, co-produced and directed by Christopher Nolan, his 7th feature film of which he has been director. The narrative follows a thief called Dom Cobb (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) who uses dream-sharing technology to steal corporate secrets. However, when approached with the task of planting an idea in a CEO's, he must recruit a team to try and complete this. This film has a star-studded lineup (although it wasn't considered this at the time of release), including Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe and many others.

Despite being renowned for having a very difficult narrative to follow, which I also found upon my first viewing, I believe that after seeing it a couple of times and suspending your disbelief, that it is an extremely clever story which Nolan is telling. Even more so knowing that it is an original screenplay.

At the time of release, as mentioned previously, the lineup were not as well-known as they are today, especially the like of Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Tom Hardy. Although, looking back at this film with the knowledge of how all of these actors and actresses developed, it is clear to see why. Every single person who stars in this film is exceptional, not a false note anywhere. There isn't a moment where I felt like I was watching a someone act, it all felt very genuine and real, which is key in making the audience suspend their disbelief, directly helping them to understand the plot further. Tom Hardy (who I am a very huge fan of for his work in Bronson, Locke, Legend etc.) really smashes this performance out of the park as the lovable Eames.

Some of the set pieces that we see in this film, the rotating hallway scene immediately comes to mind, are outstanding and even hold up to, if not surpass, those that we see in releases today. The numerous moments that made my jaw physically drop when I first saw them is what takes this film from great, to epic.

Hans Zimmer incredible score that really adds weight to the emotion that you feel sitting in the audience, cannot possibly go unmentioned. Zimmer has frequently worked with Nolan on a number of films, including The Dark Knight Trilogy, Interstellar, Dunkirk and Man Of Steel. Yet again, the two styles blend perfectly, creating a very hard hitting and tense atmosphere throughout the film, which I found especially prominent in the final scene, amplifying the "dramatic-ness" I felt.

All in all however, this is my favourite film. Christopher Nolan never fails to impress.

5/5. Quite simply one of my favourite films ever made. I've watched it so many times, and each time I see it I see something new. If you have only seen it once and you somehow didn't like it, then go see it again as you may see it in a totally different way. For essentially an action blockbuster, the plot is so complex and yet holds together better than films with more basic premises. Chris Nolan's personal and totally original masterpiece makes you think and gasp all the way through. In a world where invading and sharing dreams is possible, Leonardo DiCaprio, Ellen Page, Joesph Gordon Levitt and Tom Hardy dive deeper and deeper into Cillian Murphy' military trained subconscious in order to implant an idea. The set pieces are spell bounding and outstanding. For a film that hits the two and a half hour mark, it absolutely speeds over like freight train. Special shout out to Hans Zimmer's score which expertly integrates the fabulous Edith Paif's 'Non, je ne regrette rien'- slowing it down to create the iconic Inception BAAAAHHHMMMS, which every movie trailer now seems to 
have borrowed. Whenever this is on the TV or re-shown at a cinema near you, you simply must watch this.

This is an amazing action-packed film that forces you to think logically and quickly.
Dom and his wife have the control of their dreams. They both built their own imaginary world, which was so complex that they didn't want to leave.
Dom realizes that they can't live alone in dreams, so he implements to his wife the idea of having to commit suicide to get out of the unreal world. They throw themselves together in the front of a train to return to reality, but in Mal's mind persists the idea that she's still in a dream and that's why she must die. She drops herself from upstairs, under her husband's horrified look.
The police believes that Dom killed Mal, and the only escape off this is to run abroad to avoid being caught and convicted of murder.
Dom meets with Saito, who proposes an agreement: to enter in Fischer's mind (the heir of a big company) and to induce him to destroy the ''empire'' built by his father. In exchange for this, Saito offers him the guarantee that he will not be convicted when he gets back to America.
So, Dom forms a team with which he goes through a real adventure in the dream world, in order to explore Fischer's mind. 
Dom meets in the three dreams with his dead wife who calls him to her, but he realizes that it's not worth such a sacrifice just for a shadow of his mind.
Dom's mission ends perfectly, and Saito keeps his promise.
I'm really afraid of a world where anyone can access your brain and they can manipulate you. I hope that this technique will never be invented, and if it already exists, it should be stopped.
