Inception is an aspiring film filled with talented actors and breath-taking special effects. The premise is original enough in its own right, and offers the film an excuse to throw in as much action packed, dramatic, and thought provoking cinema without it ever seeming forced or inexplicable. With each dreamscape, layers and layers are being piled on top of our main protagonist, and by the time his arc reaches a satisfying resolution, there's been plenty of development for the rest of the cast, who play parts equally as memorable. As the audience catches up with the film, each of its 148 minutes become all the more savory, and it draws us in so much while we try to give every detail all the attention we can grasp that we feel as if we could've gotten more out of this experience than we already did, even though we received more than what we would have from various average Hollywood blockbusters these days. Inception earns its right to pleasant ponderousness.
A Complex Mind-Blowing Movie Thank You Christopher Nolan 10/10

After consecutively watching Christopher Nolan's films, it seems that one of the fundamental reasons  why Nolan has gained such a legion of followers is that he always contains a balance of separate tastes required for a wider audience. From providing the great spectacle that the big-profit films require while still maintaining and never sacrificing an intellectual depth, it's no wonder that the directors fan-demographic reflects not only the general audience, but also critics, film scholars and cinephiles alike. And while most of his movies contain this balance of action and interesting subject matter, "Inception" is undeniably Nolan's opus.

Using the mechanics of a heist narrative, Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a professional thief that  performs the art of extraction: the stealing of information from an individuals subconscious. However, after being offered the chance to return to his family, Cobb agrees to perform the difficult task of Inception: the planting of an idea within someone's dream-state (oppose to extracting it). While this is a relatively simple explanation of the plot, the execution of the narrative (like most Nolan films) is  extremely complex. Not only does Nolan employ the usual interchange between the past and present, but also a continues cycle between reality, dreams and memories. Moreover, during these various interchanges are quantities of plot details that explain the many separate mechanics that revolve around the dream-state. Although this sense of complexity is daunting, it really is one of the essential reasons why "Inception" has that everlasting quality -  its labyrinth structure is riddled with concealed secrets, even after repeated viewings. 

In terms of genre, "Inception" is a beautiful amalgamation of the directors inspirations. The 'L.A aesthetic' influenced from Mann's "Heat" is still present from "The Dark Knight" with breathtaking city imagery and also some action sequences that are clearly constructed from Nolan's Bond influence ("On Her Majesty's Secret Service"). Furthermore, there are many of the surrealist conventions that are associated with the visual representation of dreams in cinema. Although the amalgamation of these various genres could have been messy, "Inception" strucks an interesting balance between the elements of reality and the surreal. In one of the best action set-pieces that I have ever seen, Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) gets into a tussle with a henchmen (subconscious projection) in a hallway that continually rotates and eventually loses gravity. With this set-piece actually being authentically built (Nolan has said that this particular influence came from the internal designs of Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey") and without any contribution from CGI, the dichotomy between the surrealist characteristics and the reality constructions of dreams are reflected brilliantly.

While the layers to "Inception's" narrative could of possibly short-changed the leads, many of the characters - possibly -  turn out to be Nolan's best. Cobb is the directors typical unreliable narrator that once again reflects a sense of misdirection through the questioning of his perception of 'reality' (drawing many similarities to Leonard in "Memento"). With a fantastic performance provided by DiCaprio, Cobb is undeniably the emotional anchor. Along with DiCaprio, the chemistry between Arthur and Eames (Tom Hardy) adds the humour (both reflecting the classic tension between science and imagination). However, Mal (Marion Cotillard) possibly steals the show. A personification of Cobb's repressed guilt, Cotillard creates the perfect balance between demanding sympathy and being frighteningly scary.

Above all, the most astonishing achievement of "Inception" is Nolan's craftsmanship. Balancing the  interchange between the conception of dreams and reality would of obviously been a daunting task; however, the director makes it seem easy. On full display during the final forty minutes, Nolan guides the audience through four separate action sequences that are occurring simultaneously which eventuate in perfect synchronization. Essentially, even when there is action you have to pay attention. Adding to  the scope and quality of the film is Hans Zimmer's amazing score. Opening with the thunderous "The Dream is Collapsing" that accompanies an action sequence that cuts between three levels of dreams and reality sets the tone perfectly. And of course there's the beautiful melody "Time"; a musical piece that greatly adds the emotional significance to the end of Cobb's character arc.

Fundamentally, containing all of Nolan's traits on the grandest scale, there are many things to appreciate about "Inception."

Inception is an incredible movie experience unlike anything you've seen before. Written and directed by Christopher Nolan, Inception is a science fiction thriller that will leave the audience with absolutely no boundaries of constant thought from start to end - in it's 2hr 28min running time. It's a movie that requires careful focus and observance from the audience, as it's thriller filled with numerous twists and an unbelievably detailed script that's difficult to keep up with, if the level of concentration of what's going on isn't good enough. It's not the sort of movie that the filmmakers will expect the audience to understand right away; it comes with watching more than once and understanding the significance of it. 

Nolan chose a great choice of an all-star cast to star, which included: the legendary Leonardo Dicaprio, Joseph-Gordon Levitt, Marion Cotillard, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe, Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy and Michael Cain in a brief appearance.  Dicaprio plays Dom Cobb, the leading role. Cobb is a profession mind extractor, who extracts the subconscious mind of his targets in order to steal knowledge within their subconscious, through the dream world. It takes getting used to before being able to give the full explanation of what the plot centres around and the ability to extract the mind.

Nolan also had a great team of crew members to help make this movie possible, mostly ones he worked with before in movies such as the Dark Knight Trilogy. It was produced by himself and Emma Thomas; filmed by cinematographer Wally Pfister and edited by Lee Smith. Their work is well approved of and brings a whole new meaning the concentration of the mind. It was definitely worth the Academy Awards it won for it's technical categories and the accolades it won for other award ceremonies as well. 

It's definitely one of the best movies I've ever experienced and one Christopher Nolan's best!

Inception tries very hard to be ground-breaking but surprisingly I would call it below average. Inception fails in achieving everything that Nolan usually does brilliantly. Inception is one of Nolan's weakest screenplays. The people who think that Inception is a very clever and smart film are the one's who are being fooled by Nolan. The entire Act 1 was dragged and stretched and was all about about establishing rules most of which seemed to broken towards the end. In fact the rules just started to become random towards the end. The character development was very very poor. They're wooden, heartless and almost seem as though they exist as mere subjects of experimentation. The only 2 characters portrayed well were Cobb and Mal. The entire idea of "The Kick" doesn't make much sense. They started off saying that it was the effect of Gravity, the sense of falling that wakes you up. But then how is it that no one woke up when the Van was rotating and fell to a lower ground? How is it that no one woke up during the period when the Van was falling from the bridge? Why did the kick, kick in only when the Van touched the water? The introduction of Limbo is completely pointless. So if you're highly sedated, and you kill yourself in a dream, you wake up in Limbo, but if you kill yourself in Limbo you wake up? Why didn't they just think of doing that when Saito was shot. (And for some reason Saito had men working for him in Limbo as well.) The entire plot of taking over Fischer's company seems a bit too McGuffin-y. Inception took all it's ideas from an animated film called Paprika and unlike Inception, Paprika treated it's characters as humans rather than machines. This has always been Nolan's problem. The characters (in Inception, The Prestige, Insomnia and even Memento to an extent ) are so emotionless that you don't even care about most of them. That's what he got right in Batman Begins and The Dark Knight. You don't feel emotionally detached in them. There's always a risk that these types of films may outsmart themselves, I'm not sure if that's what happened with Inception but of the back of a couple of extraordinary films, one would expect better.
It isn't a casual watch, but it is a thought -provoking, inventive, and beautifully filmed with some of the best action sequences that I've seen.

I really enjoy the work of director Christopher Nolan. The Dark Knight trilogy was great, and (as of the time of this writing) Interstellar is one of the three films I'm most anticipating in the year of 2014. 

As I stated earlier in my review for Children of Men, I really enjoy science-fiction films that bring forth a new concept. Sure, there have been sci-fi films that have touched on dreams before, such as The Sphere (terrible film, by the way, I wouldn't recommend it), but not quite in the way that Inception touches it. Here, you have one of the greatest phishing schemes of all time; you bring in a team of brilliant individuals and you steal information from people by inserting yourself into their dreams and getting their subconscious to reveal that information to you. Not only does Inception give this concept a run, but it also deals with the effects (moral and psychological) of the scenario. If you spend most of your waking hours in dreams, what mental boundary separates a dream from reality? It's revolutionary concepts and Earth-shattering thoughts like this that make science-fiction what it is today, and Inception is on the frontier of the genre.

A very smart puzzle for you to solve, Inception is one of Christopher Nolan's best outside of the Batman Trilogy. This psychological action thriller follows Cobb, an extractor who possesses the ability to enter the unconscious minds and dreams of others where he can plant ideas. I used to hate this movie with a passion, yet after a third watch I've come to realise how clever and intricate this adventure is. My favourite scene sees Cobb explain to Ariadne the world of dreams, and the hostile projections that fill the landscapes, and the architectural designs are a marvel with special effects unlike any other. Watching the cafe' become surrounded by exploding objects left me with the same expression that Ellen Page pulls at this moment. The action sequences are spectacular and different to anything else out there, as the scenes cut back and forth between the dreaming extractors and the moments where they are inside the unconscious, there's a heck of a lot of creativity here and thought provoking ideas. The performances are fine thanks to a dependable cast and the writing is undeniably detailed, Inception is thrilling and worthy of a watch.

Inception demonstrates the complexity of our minds, and that dreams are the gateway to our own subconscious. The subconscious is an area of our mind that consists of things that defines us but it is an area we can't seem to fully understand. It shapes our emotions, reactions, actions, goals, connections, thoughts and understanding. The subconscious' influence is so strong that it not only hurts ourselves, but also the people around us. Inception captures that idea so well, that it requires us to watch it over and over again to gain a complete understanding of it. Sometimes its complexity would require us to take elements of the film one layer at a time as trying to understand it while taking everything in may be too much in one sitting. It has only been roughly around 4 years since the film's release and its impact on its audience has already established itself. It's cliché to say that a film is an instant classic, but that is what this film is.

The film was written by Christopher Nolan, and he has created a film that has opened our eyes to, or brought us closer in figuring out, the process of our subconscious and the dreams that are created because of it. Nolan does this in a way that serves only for the plot, it rarely ever felt like it was a lecture. The plot is quite easy to follow due to the story being goal oriented, and the film's narrative is not as fragmented as Memento or The Prestige. The film's intricacies are in its idea and it requires careful attention and multiple viewings in order for us to understand it and be satisfied. At first I felt, the level system felt too much like a video game and nothing interesting particularly happens especially during the third level, but as I kept revisiting the film, I started to find deeper themes and ideas to grasp onto, allowing me to see more of what these levels had to offer. Almost every single scene of this film is present to drive the film along, and rarely takes a breather from the mission. When it does take a break it's there to bring us closer to our protagonist and his psychological issues that may hurt his teammates along the way. I found this exploration of the character to be fascinating as it brings in familiar themes of grief and guilt and having it be wrapped in an interesting concept; going deeper in a person than we are normally accustomed to. While going through this personal journey, Nolan allows us to have a second person in the protagonist's journey, Ariadne, to represent us; trying to understand his feelings and supporting him in getting past it. There are a couple of people who might be a bit dissatisfied with the lack in connection with the film's characters, as they can easily be seen as just pieces of a game, but if one really invests themselves to the issues of our protagonist then they may be surprised on how much character development this film actually offers. The film lacks exploration on other characters, Nolan makes up for it by giving them each a personality of their own; tailored by the film's dialogue. The dialogue, along with their acting, creates these characters and reveals small things about them that make them so interesting and fun to watch. The film ends in a way that is similar to his previous films, notably Memento and The Prestige, where we are left with something ambiguous. Nolan didn't want the ending to be too easy for us, but yet he never makes us feel stupid for not getting it. It feels more like he is encouraging us to think and decide for ourselves with what we are left with.

Inception would be Christopher Nolan 7th feature film and arguably one of his best. I found this film to be much stronger than his previous film, The Dark Knight, as it equally provides the thrills and excitement that The Dark Knight had to offer but giving us something more original and thought provoking. I am impressed with Nolan's ability to handle something this complex and still manages to come out clean at the end of it, as he doesn't make us feel inferior for not understanding it. Nolan provides a sense of balance, by giving us the wonderment and ambition found in films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, and combining it with the fundamental thrills and accessibility found commonly in mainstream cinema. Without one or the other, this film would have ended up being either shallow or incoherent. This balance also prevents this film from seeming too indulgent in its writing. Nolan has simply created something ambitious but allows it to be within reach, this is something that is also achieved recently by Alfonso Cuaron in his film "Gravity". Nolan was also able to establish high stakes in the film's mission; creating a tense and gripping thriller. The film moves quite fast, as I have said before, with almost all of the scenes being there for the story. I think Nolan has spent a lot of time in the editing room with many scenes ending up in the cutting room floor. I think personally, this film would have benefited from a bit more exploration in its characters and sub-plots but I think it would have dragged on a bit too long for the casual viewer and may become restless. I found it surprising that Nolan decided to tell this story straight instead of the jagged storytelling that is found in some of his previous films. It was a great decision to tell the story this way as it would have avoided any further confusion/frustration from its audience. The film features marvellous action sequences, and since its release, has left an imprint on my mind. They are sequences that are so original, the gravity fight sequence and the manipulation of the environment's physics were notable, that it has left me in awe.

The film's director of photography was Wally Pfister and this would be his 6th collaboration with the director. Pfister is a great cinematographer but I cannot say he ranks up there with the greatest of cinematographers like Roger Deakins, Jeff Cronenweth and Emmanuel Lubezki, as Pfister never seems to make an impression with his photography, unlike these other cinematographers who leave a mark with almost all of their films. But Pfister does have the ability to create that sense of intensity and thrill, which make him the greatest choice for action-oriented films. The film was able to maintain my excitement and attention throughout, and I do think a lot of it had something to do with his photography. Pfister juggles back and forth between the hand-held camera style and the static (possibly) mounted style of shooting. This allows the film's pace to be controlled and deliver a stronger emotional response from the audience during pivotal moments in the film. Pfister, during stressful moments in the story, allows the camera to be constantly moving, following the action of the scene, going back and forth between characters during conversations. The film's photography, along with the help of the visual effects team, has created beautiful images, particularly of buildings. Pfister understood the symbolism of towering buildings and they are featured frequently throughout the film. The use of slow-motion can easily be seen as a misfire, as it often feels cliché and lacking in context, but Pfister was able to use it here with relevance, allowing the audience to be in tune with the character's sense of time. The intimate moments of the film, particularly between Mal and Cobb, worked quite well, with Pfister capturing the beauty and intensity in the actor's performance. It's brilliant of Nolan to bring the most out of his actors and relying on their ability alone to sell these types of scenes, and not having complex shots or angles in order to sell the scene.

The film's score was composed by Hans Zimmer. I have listened to a lot of film scores from Zimmer and I have picked up on some similarities within his own filmography. There were tunes in this film that reminded me of certain scenes from his earlier work like The Thin Red Line. There is enough variety in the tracks that makes each one a tune of their own, but his trademark layering is in full display on both scores. Aside from that, Inception's score is breathtaking; it is one of the very few films that can make me get goose bumps when its big notes hit. The score goes hand in hand with Nolan and Pfister's imagery, giving the film the ability in bringing up emotions from its audience. A lot of the film's score contains this thunderous low end that becomes deeper and deeper as we go further in the mission. The score seems perfect when the film follows Cobb's personal troubles, as it allows us to feel closer with the character. When Zimmer's score goes in full force at the end of the film, it hits me hard, making me feel sorrowful but at the same time satisfied.

The film's acting was for the most part good with most of its praise belonging to DiCaprio and Page. Inception isn't heavily invested in its characters, aside from its protagonist, as most of them seem to be present in service to the story. Nevertheless they were great with what they had to work with. It would have been nicer if they gave more to their characters, but this is more of an issue towards the film's writing. The ones that impressed me from the film's supporting cast include Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Marion Cotillard and Joseph Gordon Levitt. Though out of all of the supporting players, Ellen Page was the one who deserves the most praise as she was just amazing in the role as this empathetic/sympathetic woman who personally wants to help Cobb overcome his inner demons. DiCaprio in this film was brilliant as he plays this not so perfect man who is acting out of desperation to get back to his children. Out of the two films that DiCaprio was involved with during 2010, Shutter Island was the one that showcased more from the actor, as it had a much more complex character for the actor to work with. In saying this, it doesn't change the fact that his performance here was great to watch. DiCaprio's best scenes were found in the moments between him and Page or Cotillard, as his battle with his own issues brought out the best from the actor, showcasing genuine emotion and vulnerability. 

This film is Christopher Nolan's magnum opus as it features something almost completely original and he handles the film in a way that is approachable and digestible, not allowing the audience to feel inferior. It also features one of the best of Hans Zimmer's work and a standout performance from DiCaprio. Inception is one of the best films in the 21st century.

Inception is a movie that has all the right components, A great cast, interesting plot, good score, and amazing special effects. You start out thrown into the action. Leonardo DiCaprio is trying to infiltrate an Asian building to steal some secret documents. In truly dramatic fashion thousands of gallons of water come rushing through the building and you are snapped back awake to realize he has just been doused into a bath to wake him up from a shared dream. Leo and his team professionally infiltrate peoples thoughts to steal secrets, but there is a catch, if you die in the dream, you can become trapped forever. And to make matters worse, people have prepared their minds to defend themselves from attack. The movie never settles down, taking the audience through a rollercoaster of surprise plot twists and action.

Inception is a dazzling film like no other, that I believe the mind of only Christopher Nolan could create and bring to life. Though, a cast full of promising stars and a soundtrack from Hans Zimmer that makes you love the sound of your own speakers are really the only few things that Inception has going for it. For some it will take a couple viewings to fully understand what's going on inside the mind of the movie, and it definitely shouldn't be that way with a movie that has no shock value - besides within the confines of the film. Nevertheless, Nolan can deliver excitement on many different types of levels and I look forward to his work ahead.

Inception was one of the best movies of 2010 for three big reasons. First, the originality of the plot and the idea behind the movie are mind-blowing. Before Inception's release, dreams featured in films were used as motivators for the character, but the film introduces them as pivotal, interactive realities where the characters spend most of their time. Second, the characters of the movie, along with their respective actors, are top-notch, the back-stories of the characters are eloquently integrated into the film itself and the actors do marvelous jobs of portraying these roles. Finally, the many, many fan theories that have come with the movie, anything from the ending scene with the spinning top, the totems for characters, Cobb's totem, and the soundtrack, etc. 
The point is that this movie is so well thought out that it spawned literally thousands of blogs and debates involving these many theories and ideas. Inception is a brilliant movie, it has a phenomenal cast and plot, and shall remain as one of my all time favorites.

Wow this film is so overrated. I brought this film because everyone was raving about how amazing it is and for ages I had wanted to see this. I seem to be the only person who doesn't really like or get this film. The film is about Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio)who steals information from people's subconscious when they are sleeping, however he is offered a new mission, to plant an idea in someone's dream. Inception is so confusing that I literally had no idea what was going on most of the time. The acting was really good though; Leonardo Di Caprio is a great actor and I usually like his films. I was glad Joseph Gordon-Levitt was in this as he's also a good actor and I have a bit of crush on him and Leonardo DiCaprio. Tom Hardy and Ellen Page were also really good in this; Tom Hardy was actually quite funny. 

However I just really don't understand this film; there's so much going on and so much to take in and so many characters. There's too much action and I just found it really boring. The storyline is just so ridiculous and there's no substance; you don't really get a chance to connect with the characters. I think this is definitely more of a guy film. This film is really overrated, I'm so disappointed. Inception is just as hazy, forgettable and devoid of concreteness like a dream and that's not a good thing. I didn't even think the dreams were realistic portrayals of true dreams, it was people resuming their awaking life, but in dream form. 

Grade: D-

If someone told you, you were going to be spending the next 2 hours and 30 minutes watching a film about dreams, you'd be forgiven for gearing up for a confusing and pretencious mess that no doubt has a twist ending, and while this isnt exactly untrue with Inception, it does what most other films about dreams, scratch that blockbusters, fail to even come close to, a riveting, thunderous and emotional beast, that flies along and leaves you going "No way!" by the completely unexpected ending. By now, unless you have been living under a rock or 40 fathoms under the sea, you will no doubt at the very least know of the existence of Inception, the film that was wedged between The Dark Knight and The Dark Knight Rises in Christopher Nolan's monumental canon. Inception follows a man called Cobb, a professional thief, who has been forced into a world of the unorthodox of manipulating his subjects dreams, in order to extract essential information, from their brains, in order to sell to his clients. On one botched mission, Cobb and his right hand man Arthur manage to impress one of their subjects so much, he tracks the couple down and offers Cobb an opportunity he cannot refuse. All Cobb has to do, something that supposidly has never been done before, Inception, a process where a team must implant the seed of an idea in someones dream, allowing it to grow into fruitation, to change their future and which defines them. Cobb of course takes the job, for a reason I wont spoil here and as he races to assemble a team and actually execute Inception, we are treated to a maze of side winding exposition, character arcing, impressive set pieces and a multitude of philosopy and science. Upon release, many people complained about being able to follow Inception, as the films core mechanics revolve around our characters being in dreams within dreams, within dreams, however, what Nolan has actually done here is take what would have, in a lesser directors hands, be extremely unpallatable and made it accessable to a mainstream audience, while not offending people who dont like to be spoon fed information and concept and it is an absolute marvel to behold. The film literally weaves in and out of scenes at a break neck speed, the film maker inside me wonders, how tedious the script writing process and story boarding would have been. This film is just as complexly constructed as the Inception itself and its only on repeat viewings, you are able to marvel at its wonderful structure of many layers. The cast first of all, is literally what many independent directors would call a wet dream, however for Nolan, something of this caliber is of the norm. Leonardo Dicaprio, Tom Hardy, Ellen Paige, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Cillian Murphey, Ken Watanabe, Michael Caine, Tom Berenger and Marion Cotillard make up a fantastic cast that are all on top of their game, I wouldnt go as far as to say any of these actors do their best work in this film, however its extremely close. The genius with Inception's cast is their ability to work as part of such a large ensemble, be completely believable and convey all the subtle emotions needed to make this jolt at the heart strings, while injecting comedy at every turn. Usually with large casts like this, the bigger message can be lost, however here, every single actor is important and completely aware of the end result. Leo as Cobb, could be slandered, unfairly, for pulling out something similar to Shutter Island, which was also released in the same year, but doing so would be extremely unfair. He is one of the greatest actors of our time, like it or not, he is an intense character actor, one that is so good, you dont know he is acting and that makes him perfect for this role. You buy into his psychological intensity, you buy into his emotional reasoning, you buy into his intelligence and its all because of Leo's power to really carry a film on his own back, if Inception had got this casting wrong, it would have completely crumbled at the foundations, however Leo totally rams it home, while allowing his supporting actors to thrive and at points outshine him. Levitt had always been a heart throb full of cheek and carisma, however here he gets to really cement himself as Arthur, Leo's most trusted colleague, who acts as Cobb's sensible concious. Arthur is constantly trying to help Cobb survive, however he cant control him and he knows it, however Levitt, really sells the actions, he sells the relationship and he is completely under rated within this film. Ellen Paige also gets a wonderful part to play as Ariadne, a young, budding architect, who is forced to construct the mazes, that Cobb's team need in order to implant Inception within their victims mind. This could have easily been a throwaway character, but here Nolan gives her so much more to do, allowing her to act as the audiences gateway into Cobb's psyche, she also acts like a form of reason and Cobb takes massive risks with her, due to his trusting nature and his admiration of her character. Paige nails it as a younger character, walking into the worlds biggest play ground, she is reckless, however completely enveloped in the dream world. Other cast members add a wealth of strength behind the ensemble Watanabe, Berenger and Caine really nail what they are given to work with, but the some of the films best work, apart from Leo, comes from Hardy, Cotillard and of course Murphey. Hardy is so lovable as Eaves, someone Cobb must entrust to morph into the subjects most trusted family member and having a method actor like Hardy, take on this role, is a stroke of genius, it also really enthralls as his frayed relationship with Arthur continually brings comic relief. Talking about the subject, Murphy is wonderful as Fischer Jr, the son of a wealthy entrepeneur on his death bed, who he believes his father resented his very existance for his entire life. He plays the part in such a way only Murphy could and the result is a stroke of genius. Cotillard is however one of Inceptions unsung heroes, its extremely hard to give a detailled account of her character without ruining some form of plot, but all you need to know is that she is frighteningly thunderous as an extremely important character, within this puzzle. The script is brilliantly constructed, it interlaces the philosphies of life, the subconcious, love, longing, experimentation, addiction, psychosis, science, trust, friendship, abuse, manipulation, corruption... I could go on all day, but the dialogue is never yawn inducing, it never bores you with its themes, instead it gives you all you need to know to advance the plot at any given time, allowing the actors to input their own colour onto the palette. As mentioned earlier, its difficult to conceive how Nolan actually wrote this script, Inception bounces all over the place, from actual events across the globe at any given time, deep into multi layered dreams and its completely evident that he must have put a tremendous amount of time and effort into this one. I can just imagine him sitting in a dark room with boards and boards of notes, ramblings and doodles scattered all over, in order to keep track of the overall goal here. Wally Pfister is also on top of his game here, helping Nolan bring his vision to life, he really manages to create a brilliant and semi original take on the dream world, while integrating a real life that seems just as similar to dreams themself and later on as the dreams become more adventurous, its clear Pfister is in his element, from massive sandy beaches to snow covered fortresses, the scale this man actually manages to capture is fucking jaw dropping. It also has to be said, unsurprisingly, that Nolan clearly has a fetish for 2001: A Space Oddissey, as he litterally steals a multitude of techniques and actual concepts from that film alone, usually it would be aggrivating but their inclusion is dealt with such wonder and with such a brilliant spin, you will be hard pressed not to sitting biting your nails as to how, in camera, him and Pfister filmed them. The editing also is extremely commendable, being able to hold the pacing and multi threads going on at any given time, would swamp a lesser editor, but here, the man responsible is just all over it, keeping cuts snappy, on the beat and extremely on the button. Finally Hans Zimmers scores are always commendable pieces of genius, but this may be his master piece, the score literally jolts the movie from brilliant to stratospheric, conveying so much emotion and scale, having another form of art slapped on top to really ram home the emotion of the piece is extremely commendable and its important for its inclusion here as at points its easy to see why some of the emotion, may just drown a little from all the contextual weight. For all that is commendable, Inception is guilty of a few minor niggles, that stop it from being a total masterpiece. First off, with any film this bold, its story can be slightly picked apart, there are a few glaring plot holes within the story that although dont effect you directly, due to the films sheer speed, upon watching multiple times, you start to pick apart just how capable this is. Convienance is the best example, at so many points it this movie, we the audience are forced to believe that so many pivotal events happen, purely down to a lack of coincidence, for example Saito, who employs Cobb after a botched attempt to extract information from his dreams, just so happens to find Cobb again and Cobb just so happens to be the only man ever to have achieved Inception, he also happens to be the entity that Nolan feels the need to throw off all the plot points or moments he cant find a resolute to, problem with getting the subject under Saito buys the airline, Saito just happens to be Cobb's only link back to home, which then is utilized to add tension by putting his life in continual danger. These are minor points, but they start adding up, pretty quickly. Another is Ariadne's reluctance to tell the others of Cobb's trouble and of Cobb to realize the extent of his damage, yes he obviously will stop at nothing to get home, but there are points when he is completely aware of his demons, yet for the films sake of tension, decides to be completely blinded by them, in order to further the films running time. I am of course nitpicking now but I cant help going, you know this would have all been over by now if they had simply done this or simply done that. All convienace aside Inception is one of the greatest achievements in modern day, blockbusting cinema, its big, bold, loud, fun, intelligent and jaw dropping. A wonderful film, toned back slightly by plotting, by on the grand scheme of things, it is an absolute must watch.

Christopher Nolan's INCEPTION (2010) is my favorite movie of all time, as well as the movie that actually got me into filmmaking in the first place. An immense inspiration in my life, Inception is without a doubt the epitome of awesomeness. This movie is an extremely well written, well thought out, superbly acted, emotional film that has become a milestone in film history as well as my life-hands down one of the BEST FILMS of all time. This movie is such a great feat-a cinematic masterpiece in my opinion-in terms of how Nolan executed storytelling and the astounding performances he brought out of talented actors such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Marion Cotillard, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Cillian Murphy, and Ken Watanabe; Inception also excels in all of its technical aspects too: score, cinematography, visual effects, and features one of the coolest action sequences that's been done with ONLY practical effects (Nolan is a big fan of practical over visual). As a matter of fact, for those who have seen the film, the hotel hallway fight sequence and the Penrose steps, among other parts of Inception, are ALL PRACTICAL EFFECTS. There were only 500 VFX shots total as compared to what ordinary sci-fi movies today would have: about 2000.

The film revolves around Dom Cobb (DiCaprio) a man who infiltrates a person's subconscious using dream sharing technology and then steals their ideas; a job known as extraction. However he's been struggling to find a way back to his kids, but the only way he can do that is to perform inception on Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy) the son of a dying business magnate-all part of a deal with Saito (Ken Watanabe) the head of the company that rivals Fischer's. Unlike extraction (which Cobb is supposedly the best at), inception is the extremely difficult art of IMPLANTING an idea into the subject's mind instead. In order to accomplish inception he assembles a team-consisting of Arthur (JGL), who assembles all the information needed about the subject; Ariadne (Ellen Page), the architect who builds each dream layer; Eames (Tom Hardy), an identity forger who impersonates other people in the dream to manipulate the subject; and finally Yusuf (Dileep Rao), a chemist who creates the compounds needed for the dream sharing technology. What follows is an extremely complex, thrilling, mind bending, and thought provoking adventure into the world of dreams!! If that doesn't excite you then I don't know what will.

For those who don't actually know Nolan had actually wanted to make the film after Insomnia (2002) and the studio also approved. However he wanted to write a spec script first and then go back to the studio when he was finished... Except it took another 8 years to fully develop and craft out this ingenious screenplay of people entering another man's dreams, and essentially changing the man's whole perception of certain aspects of his life. I absolutely hate it when people say this movie is "confusing". There's a difference between a confusing movie and a movie that MAKES THE AUDIENCE THINK. Also, the characters actually do explain practically everything one would need to know to follow their mission. It is NOT confusing.

DiCaprio gives one of his best performances ever as this grief stricken man with a mysterious past who is attempting to do what many would deem impossible. FUN FACT: Will Smith and Brad Pitt were both considered for the role of Cobb as well. But, while I love those actors, I honestly don't think they could have pulled the role off as amazing as DiCaprio did. Cobb is a professional, but at this point in his life he's the most desperate man ever who is willing to endanger his team members for the sake of being with his family-and DiCaprio perfectly portrayed this character. I kid you not this is my favorite performance from DiCaprio, and his chemistry with the others was incredible. Marion Cotillard plays his wife, Mal, in the film who appears as a projection whenever Cobb is in the dream state. I don't want to delve too much into her character because there are certain aspects that everyone should experience for themselves; but, to put it simply, she was awesome.

HOWEVER, one of the standout actors in the film was Cillian Murphy as Fischer. Although he's being manipulated and is technically a pawn in the mission, this guy was still going on his own personal journey in coming to terms with his frail relationship with his father. And for those who have not seen it... SPOILERS! The moment Fischer's father (Pete Postlethwaite) says "I was disappointed... that you tried..." and then Fischer opens the safe and pulls out that pinwheel with Hans Zimmer's fantastical score playing in the background.... Holy shit what an unbelievable scene, with a magnificent performance from Murphy! Literally my jaw dropped and I was actually on the verge of tears. Just... Wow! That ties with the hallway scene for my favorite scene in the film, though it's definitely one of the most emotional scenes.

Inception was also the movie in which I was introduced to both Tom Hardy and JGL, two of my favorite actors working today to be honest. I loved both their characters, especially Eames whose role in the mission was really fascinating to me. But everyone please give a huge round of applause to JGL for both his acting and commitment to the action sequences; he did almost all of them including the infamous hallway scene. I had seen Ellen Page in Juno before Inception, but I have to say I loved Ariadne over Juno for multiple reasons; one of which being Ariadne was a far more adult and serious character than Juno. I have to fight with anyone who says, "She's just their so we can understand the plot. Other than that she's useless...." NOPE. I believe that she's one of the most essential team members especially since she acts as an anchor to Cobb whenever he drifts away from reality now and then (of course she finds out certain things about him that allow her to be an anchor but that's SPOILER territory). I also love the character in general, she's more than just a proxy to the audience; Ariadne is an intelligent, curious, and courageous girl and Ellen Page gives the performance of her life here. Her chemistry with Cobb was astoundingly good and without her the film would definitely be missing something special. And finally Watanabe's Saito... EPIC! I loved him in this more than Batman Begins, but a tier below The Last Samurai (underrated Tom Cruise film by the way). His relationship with Cobb was really cool to see developed throughout the film and Watanabe brings everything to the role.

Now we have to finally come to Hans Zimmer's score... To put it simply FUCKING INCREDIBLE!!! I cannot believe he didn't win the Oscar for Best Original Score. In the opening scene alone when (SPOILERS-it's so hard to gush about a movie I love when I can't talk about everything!) Saito reveals to Cobb that he knows he's dreaming and then the "Dream is Collapsing" song kicks in-how badass was that and the continuing action that follows?! I love every single one of Zimmer's beautiful melodies in Inception, and they were essential to tying together this cohesive story and bringing out some great character moments as well. And he popularized the "BRAAM" SFX and gave us "Time" which happens to be a lot of people's favorites (for me it's always going to be "Dream is Collapsing"). As for Wally Pfister's cinematography: remarkable. Every shot, every scene was beautiful in terms lighting, framing, etc. Also, the color palette for Inception is amazing and if you go back and watch it you'll see that each dream layer (on the actual mission) has a different variety of colors; this allows each level to have its own distinct look and vibe. Overall visuals in the film are spectacular.

I think it's come to the point where Inception is now a legendary movie (coincidentally it's produced by Legendary Pictures). Even to this day we are still talking about this grand film, especially because of that AMBIGUOUS ENDING. Is Cobb still in a dream? Of course Nolan himself said that the ending is supposed to mean that Cobb has stopped obsessing over dreams... But it's so fun to speculate. Personally I say he's in reality, but sound off in the comments what your thoughts are on it.

If I've noticed any pattern in Nolan's films it's that he keeps increasing the scope in every single one of them. I mean could anyone but him pull of that quadruple kick at the very end of the film, have it make sense and look fantastic at the same time? Every time he gets more and more ambitious, and Inception could have easily been a convoluted mess. In all honesty it COULD have been such an atrocity; but Nolan flawlessly directed this film. No matter how complicated things got I still understood what was happening and was purely entertained throughout; without a doubt Inception was one of the best film going experiences in my life. Like an idea, the film has come to define who I am today. It had emotion, action, tidbits of comedy; it serves as both a sci-fi espionage, a drama, a high octane thriller. It's just... INCEPTION!! If you haven't seen it- Actually why the hell would you have not seen it by now? Watch it! Sorry; experience the pure cinematic awesomeness that is Christopher Nolan's masterpiece: Inception - 100/10

Original in plot, stunning visually, mesmerizing cinematically, elegant in composition, and boasting entertaining performances from the entire cast; Christopher Nolan delivers on a film 10 years in the making, giving us one of the most awe inspiring masterpieces of decades past. Inception is unique and thrilling. Nolan gives us an innovative world where people invade other peoples dreams and plant an idea in their head. Sounds boring, but the movie is so well executed and absolutely exciting. The cast all brings their A-game, and the special effects are spectacular. The score is epic and accompanies the intense movie. The action is exciting and the movie is very well paced. In such a complicated film, you would assume there would be many plot holes, but Nolan's excellent direction uses exposition to explain this crazy universe to us. The characters are well fleshed out, especially Cobb's emotionally powerful past. Others are given less to do, but are each given distinctive professions. In the end Inception is a really dazzling and smart summer blockbuster. Inception gets 5/5 stars (A+).

Inception demonstrates the complexity of our minds, and that dreams are the gateway to our own subconscious. The subconscious is an area of our mind that consists of things that defines us but it is an area we can't seem to fully understand. It shapes our emotions, reactions, actions, goals, connections, thoughts and understanding. The subconscious' influence is so strong that it not only hurts ourselves, but also the people around us. Inception captures that idea so well, that it requires us to watch it over and over again to gain a complete understanding of it. Sometimes it's complexity would require us to take elements of the film one layer at a time as trying to understand it while taking everything in may be too much in one sitting. It has only been roughly around 4 years since the film's release and it's impact on it's audience has already established itself. It's cliche to say that a film is an instant classic, but that is what this film is.

The film was written by Christopher Nolan, and he has created a film that has opened our eyes to, or brought us closer in figuring out, the process of our subconscious and the dreams that are created because of it. Nolan does this in a way that serves only for the plot, it rarely ever felt like it was a lecture. The plot is quite easy to follow due to the story being goal oriented, and the film's narrative is not as fragmented as Memento or The Prestige. The film's intricacies are in it's idea and it requires careful attention and multiple viewings in order for us to understand it and be satisfied. At first I felt, the level system felt too much like a video game and nothing interesting particularly happens especially during the third level, but as I kept revisiting the film, I started to find deeper themes and ideas to grasp onto, allowing me to see more of what these levels had to offer. Almost every single scene of this film is present to drive the film along, and rarely takes a breather from the mission. When it does take a break it's there to bring us closer to our protagonist and his psychological issues that may hurt his teammates along the way. I found this exploration of the character to be fascinating as it brings in familiar themes of grief and guilt and having it be wrapped in an interesting concept; going deeper in a person than we are normally accustomed to. While going through this personal journey, Nolan allows us to have a second person in the protagonist's journey, Ariadne, to represent us; trying to understand his feelings and supporting him in getting past it. There are a couple of people who might be a bit dissatisfied with the lack in connection with the film's characters, as they can easily be seen as just pieces of a game, but if one really invests themselves to the issues of our protagonist then they may be surprised on how much character development this film actually offers. The film lacks exploration on other characters, Nolan makes up for it by giving them each a personality of their own; tailored by the film's dialogue. The dialogue, along with their acting, creates these characters and reveals small things about them that makes them so interesting and fun to watch. The film ends in a way that is similar to his previous films, notably Memento and The Prestige, where we are left with something ambiguous. Nolan didn't want the ending to be too easy for us, but yet he never makes us feel stupid for not getting it. It feels more like he is encouraging us to think and decide for ourselves with what we are left with.

Inception would be Christopher Nolan 7th feature film and arguably one of his best. I found this film to be much stronger than his previous film, The Dark Knight, as it equally provides the thrills and excitement that The Dark Knight had to offer but giving us something more original and thought provoking. I am impressed with Nolan's ability to handle something this complex and still manages to come out clean at the end of it, as he doesn't make us feel inferior for not understanding it. Nolan provides a sense of balance, by giving us the wonderment and ambition found in films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, and combining it with the fundamental thrills and accessibility found commonly in mainstream cinema. Without one or the other, this film would have ended up being either shallow or incoherent. This balance also prevents this film from seeming too indulgent in it's writing. Nolan has simply created something ambitious but allows it to be within reach, this is something that is also achieved recently by Alfonso Cuaron in his film "Gravity". Nolan was also able to establish high stakes in the film's mission; creating a tense and gripping thriller. The film moves quite fast, as I have said before, with almost all of the scenes being there for the story. I think Nolan has spent a lot of time in the editing room with many scenes ending up in the cutting room floor. I think personally, this film would have benefited from a bit more exploration in it's characters and sub-plots but I think it would have dragged on a bit too long for the casual viewer and may become restless. I found it surprising that Nolan decided to tell this story straight instead of the jagged storytelling that is found in some of his previous films. It was a great decision to tell the story this way as it would have avoided any further confusion/frustration from it's audience. The film features marvelous action sequences, and since it's release, has left an imprint on my mind. They are sequences that are so original, the gravity fight sequence and the manipulation of the environment's physics were notable, that it has left me in awe.

The film's director of photography was Wally Pfister and this would be his 6th collaboration with the director. Pfister is a great cinematographer but I cannot say he ranks up there with the greatest of cinematographers like Roger Deakins, Jeff Cronenweth and Emmanuel Lubezki, as Pfister never seems to make an impression with his photography, unlike these other cinematographers who leave a mark with almost all of their films. But Pfister does have the ability to create that sense of intensity and thrill, which make him the greatest choice for action-oriented films. The film was able to maintain my excitement and attention throughout, and I do think a lot of it had something to do with his photography. Pfister juggles back and forth between the hand-held camera style and the static (possibly) mounted style of shooting. This allows the film's pace to be controlled and deliver a stronger emotional response from the audience during pivotal moments in the film. Pfister, during stressful moments in the story, allows the camera to be constantly moving, following the action of the scene, going back and forth between characters during conversations. The film's photography, along with the help of the visual effects team, has created beautiful images, particularly of buildings. Pfister understood the symbolism of towering buildings and they are featured frequently throughout the film. The use of slow-motion can easily be seen as a misfire, as it often feels cliche and lacking in context, but Pfister was able to use it here with relevance, allowing the audience to be in tune with the character's sense of time. The intimate moments of the film, particularly between Mal and Cobb, worked quite well, with Pfister capturing the beauty and intensity in the actor's performance. It's brilliant of Nolan to bring the most out of his actors and relying on their ability alone to sell these type of scenes, and not having complex shots or angles in order to sell the scene.

The film's score was composed by Hans Zimmer. I have listened to a lot of film scores from Zimmer and I have picked up on some similarities within his own filmography. There were tunes in this film that reminded me of certain scenes from his earlier work like The Thin Red Line. There is enough variety in the tracks that makes each one a tune of their own, but his trademark layering is in full display on both scores. Aside from that, Incpetion's score is breathtaking; it is one of the very few films that can make me get goosebumps when it's big notes hit. The score goes hand in hand with Nolan and Pfister's imagery, giving the film the ability in bringing up emotions from it's audience. A lot of the film's score contains this thunderous low end that becomes more deeper and deeper as we go further in the mission. The score seems perfect when the film follows Cobb's personal troubles, as it allows us to feel closer with the character. When Zimmer's score goes in full force at the end of the film, it hits me hard, making me feel sorrowful but at the same time satisfied.

The film's acting was for the most part good with most of it's praise belonging to DiCaprio and Page. Inception isn't heavily invested in it's characters, aside from it's protagonist, as most of them seem to be present in service to the story. Nevertheless they were great with what they had to work with. It would have been nicer if they gave more to their characters, but this is more of an issue towards the film's writing. The ones that impressed me from the film's supporting cast include Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Marion Cotillard and Joseph Gordon Levitt. Though out of all of the supporting players, Ellen Page was the one who deserves the most praise as she was just amazing in the role as this empathetic/sympathetic woman who personally wants to help Cobb overcome his inner demons. DiCaprio in this film was brilliant as he plays this not so perfect man who is doing all that he can to get back to his children. Out of the two films that DiCaprio was involved with during 2010, Shutter Island was the one that showcased more from the actor, as it had a much more complex character for the actor to work with. In saying this, it doesn't change the fact that his performance here was great to watch. DiCaprio's best scenes were found in the moments between him and Page or Cotillard, as his battle with his own issues brought out the best from the actor, showcasing genuine emotion and vulnerability. 

This film is Christopher Nolan's magnum opus as it features something almost completely original and he handles the film in a way that is approachable and digestible, not allowing the audience to feel inferior. It also features one of the best of Hans Zimmer's work and a standout performance from DiCaprio. Inception is one of the best films in the 21st century.

{{ [[PLOT]] Dominick Cobb(Leonardo DiCaprio) is an extractor(information thief through dreams) wanting to return to his home in U.S. to live with his 2 children where his entry is restricted due to charges of murder. Arthur(Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is his partner/point man who researches a  subject - which is a person from whom information is to be stolen. The information is stolen through shared dreaming where both Cobb and Arthur enter the dream of the subject and manipulate the subject who is unaware of the dreaming state to reveal information. There are many rules and should-know things about the dream state and shared dreaming. Cobb is offered a task which is thought to be impossible by a powerful businessman Saito(Ken Watanabe) succeeding in completing it will clear him of his criminal charges and he will be able to come back home to live with his children. For the task Cobb assembles a team which includes a forger Eames(Tom Hardy), an architect Ariadne(Ellen Page) and a chemist Yusuf(Dileep Rao) and has to tackle the memory of his dead wife Mal(Marion Cotillard) in his subconscious while dreaming. The to-do job is nothing but using multiple levels of dreaming to plant an idea in a subjects mind and the task is called "INCEPTION" }}

 Well Inception has so many small details that catching them all while understanding the story is an uphill task. In the first hour we are made familiar with concepts of dreaming and rest of the movie reveals the inception. The movie has no single perfect interpretation where everyone can come up with his/her own version of the story and that's the beauty of it. The more you try to dwell the more intricate it becomes. At the end definitely you will be exhausted and confused that you are bound to discuss with others or search the internet for answers!
 Among the some memorable scenes are a zero-gravity fighting scene, the ending scene with Hans Zimmer's music at its best and many Hans Zimmer "moments" with his dense background score. Inception won Oscar for Best Visual effects and I was trying to remember where did they use so much CGI? That's how little it was used and what was used, made it look so real that questions rose on the concept of reality. Also the Oscar for the Best Cinematography (Wally Pfister) was very well deserved. Leo DiCaprio gives a rock-solid performance which will be remembered for a very long time and entire cast justify their roles perfectly. Inception with its story by itself would have been a great film but it's the music by Zimmer that takes it to entirely different level. The combo Nolan-Zimmer never fails!

On the whole Inception is a phenomenon not to be missed! I am blessed to be alive in the era of Christopher Nolan and his masterpieces and for me Inception is not only his but an all-time best!!

Nolan has given us The Dark Knight,The Prestige,Insomnia,Memento.And now he has given us Inception,a film which challenges to you to imagine and think something so interesting,that you will want more and more questions answered.
 Dom Cobb(Caprio)is a thief.He does not steal cars,money or anything that we have seen in our most loved movies so far.He steals ideas.In a world of corporate espionage,Cobb is what every business man would want.This is not legal.However,Cobb is given the daunting task of planting an idea.Inception.This is something which has never been done,and requires skilled people.What follows reminded me of Oceans Eleven.We see Cobb recruit some of the finest people for this job and start on his mission which will either make him or break him.
 Nolan takes what is common to all of us-dreams-and plays along with it.The concept of dreams is delved into really well.For example,the scene where Cobb asks Ariadne how we seem to never really remember how the dream began is sheer brilliance.Inception is a benchmark for science-fiction films as it manages to do both-make us think and also provide us with some amazingly well done spercial effects.
 Special mention should be given to Hans Zimmer,who has composed the music for this film.Some scenes would definitely lose their brilliance had it not been for his background music.Inception is a sure shot winner,scoring in all ways possible.Indeed,with Inception,it is for certain that Nolan is a man with a gift for filmmaking(and writing too,as the story for the movie was written by him)

"What is the most resilient parasite? Bacteria? A virus? An intestinal worm? An idea. Resilient... highly contagious. Once an idea has taken hold of the brain it's almost impossible to eradicate. An idea that is fully formed - fully understood - that sticks; right in there somewhere."

Christopher Nolan is without a doubt the greatest modern filmmaker that Hollywood has involved in the past decade. His films are creative, filled with compelling themes and ideas, and dedicates himself in telling a remarkable story over stellar visuals. Every great filmmaker has their passion project. For George Lucas, it was Star Wars. For James Cameron, Avatar. For Steven Spielberg, ET. And for Christopher Nolan, it would be Inception, which will go down in film history as one of the most complex, insane, and highly original movies ever made.

Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a thief who has the power to enter people's dreams to steal ideas, becoming the ultimate weapon in corporate espionage. But Cobb has a lot of personal problems, which is affecting his Inception project; his late wife (Marion Cotillard) is haunting his every thought, and, accused of murdering her, isn't allowed to see his children nor step foot on American soil. With one last shot at redemption, Cobb and his "dream team" (which compromises of a talented cast like Tom Hardy, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, and Ken Watanbe) turn from stealing ideas into planting one, a quest that could bring Cobb back to his children. But the more they go into Robert Fischer's (Cillian Murphy) mind, the more complicated the mission gets.

I first saw Inception back in 2010, and thought nothing special about it. My initial reaction was that the story was way too complicated to enjoy, but the cast and ideas were great. Four years later, with a more appreciative mind on complex material, and the first time I've seen Inception since my initial thoughts, I can now say that Inception is a modern Nolanesque masterpiece. 

For one thing, look at how original and creative the story is, particularly the rules of going into the mind. When you die in the dream, you instantly wake up. When you're in multiple layers of the dream, you need a massive "kick" to get out of it. And the detail goes on and on and on, and the result is brilliantly executed. In a world dominated by sequels, prequels, reboots, and ripoffs of great original material already executed in the past, it's a miracle that someone is dedicated to telling something 100% original, and create a near-flawless film.

But my original problem still resonates with the film, that the story can get a little too complicated to follow. When looking at the film, a thought came in my mind. You know, this is Inception. The plot's supposed to make you think. It's not like Nolan wants to go kindergarten teacher on us and make a Cliff Note version on a project that took him ten long, hard years to make! This is Inception, not The Wizard of Oz! Considering the complexity and the multiple layers of thought in watching the film, you got to give Nolan credit for creating a film where you have to think throughout. It's something that hasn't been perfected since the films of Alfred Hitchcock. And that's something to be proud of.


Unlike Gravity, where the visuals were the star of the show, Nolan makes sure that story comes first, then create stellar visual effects. And they are some of the best visual works in the past decade, more so than Gravity, Avatar, and Life of Pi combined! When you have a film involving revolving hallways, buildings going on top of each other, a van flying off a bridge in slo-mo for at least 30 minutes, and trains going beserk on the streets, you know this is an epic genius masterpiece. To be honest, I have no clue how Nolan and the visual crew managed to do it. And that's also something to be proud of, as not knowing how to create something visually wonderful is always a massive achievement.

Casting is something Nolan is good at, and in Inception, Nolan doesn't disappoint. While I'm not much of a Leonardo DiCaprio fan (mostly because the only films I've seen him in are this and that horrendous modernized adaptation of Romeo and Juliet), I must say I was impressed with what DiCaprio pulls on the table. In the first minutes, we automatically root for Cobb in his shot at redemption. Leap of faith is a major plot device in the film, particularly in giving DiCaprio's character room to grow in the continuing issue of his dreams and others. I'm surprised he didn't get an Oscar nomination for his captivating performance, but it is what it is. Tom Hardy? Awesome, nuff said. Joseph Gordon-Levitt? Great, as usual. Ellen Page? Well, considering she's not one of my favorite actresses, Nolan makes her about as compelling is drama as DiCaprio! Marion Cotillard? Wonderful, complex performance! Ken Watanbe? Enjoyable in being the overly-serious guy! Cillain Murphy? His most compelling performance, having issues in what to do in life and is the best performance I've seen in him, much more chilling than Scarecrow! There's also a very entertaining appearance from the always great Michael Caine. 

Hans Zimmer is one of the most original modern composers out there. And in Inception, his originality doesn't stop! Considering I'm not that big a fan of techno-sounding, as proven in that highly overrated Steven Price Gravity score, but Zimmer always knows what to do, and his score is flawless, possibly one of his greatest scores ever!!! The unique instrumentation fits in well with the complex material of the film, and the main theme is AWESOME!!!!!!!!!  

There's been debate on what Nolan's masterwork is, Inception or The Dark Knight. It's a really tough debate, and considering I initially thought Inception to be slightly overrated, I have seen the massive acclaim on it, and with that said, Inception is one of Nolan's best. It doesn't top The Dark Knight, but with it's great performances, particularly Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy, and Leonardo DiCaprio, stellar visual making, a genius ending that raises lots of questions, and original, thought-provoking ideas and one of the most highly creative modern blockbusters in the past 14 years, Inception comes really, really close. It's great that the Academy recognized Nolan for his phenomenal work on Inception, considering all the Oscars it won, after the massive snubs they gave on all three Batman films combined, but with the upcoming Interstellar looking to be another original masterpiece as Inception, it's safe to say that hopefully, he'll have a Best Picture or Best Director win in his resume.

I am one of the biggest fan of the great Christopher Nolan so much so that I was always a subject to taunt among my peers, but none the less I feel he is one of the best storyteller of the recent years and I can go on lengths to prove that. Now having said that Inception in my view is the best film he has done yet. Inception is a crime thriller mostly dealing with our dreams. Leonardo DiCaprio as Dom Cobb is the Con artist here who can extract anything from your subconscious mind in dreams. It's a story of a major hiest through which Dom finds redemption from his inner guilt. The story features of a great cast indeed. Besides DiCaprio we have Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ken Watanabe, Cillian Murphy and the ever reliable Michael Caine in important roles and every one contributes to this epic. 

There are particular instances which are so moving, like the one where Mal jumps out of the building and the emotional portions involving Dicaprio. Dicaprio has really grown as an actor over the years. He may tend to overdo the pain stricken characters but none the less he is too good at that. 

A special mention needs to be done for the effects. A lot of new things have been tried here and everything looks so beautiful. Be it the scene where the whole of Paris folds itself, or the gravity defying action scenes everything seems well rehearsed and truly breathtaking. The back ground score by Hans Zimmer is truly amazing.

All in all Inception to me is the best cinematic experience I have ever had and believe me I am not a novice in this field. The screen play is so binding, the characters are well built, the plot is mind blowing and the direction is top notch. So I am going 10 out of 10 for Christopher Nolan's Inception. It's my favourite film and honestly it challenged me to my wit's end to figure it out.

Years later, I still think this is one of the most overrated movies of all time. All concept-based and not based on heart or depth of character development. I could care less about any of these characters. Loved Matrix, Dark City, and even Nolan's other work, Memento, which many would say is also complicated and based on a new concept (though I believe Memento is much more intriguing than Inception). This movie is too focused on explaining and showing the dream within dreams concept and the worlds within them, that the character and story development are sorely neglected. I do not care what happens to the characters; therefore, I find the movie pointless. Besides the concepts it offers, it does not touch the heart. The characters do not actualize, and even in stories where characters are stagnant or regress, at least I care what happens to them, but not in this film. Of course, there are people who love this film so much and cannot imagine why anyone would not love it who claim that people who don't like the movie are either too dumb to understand it and cannot follow the movie, the concepts in the movie, or the plot. These snobs and bullies think that they must call anyone else who do not like the movie not intelligent enough to follow it. It's fascinating how these people think that one simply cannot follow a movie when the concepts and what is happening are clearly and repeatedly explained throughout the entire film. The constant explaining of why this is happening and what is happening is actually part of the reason why I do not like this movie. I wanted to learn about why things are happening for myself. You'd actually have to be really dim or simply not paying attention to not understand what is happening in this movie as it explains itself throughout the whole process. In the other three movies I mentioned previously above, the viewer has to more or less discover for him or herself what is happening on their own, without the constant explaining of the concepts. I believe the concept and the visual effects, along with the explanations and narratives make it a lot easier for the masses to understand this movie. I found it distracting to be told what is happening constantly. The ending was one of the few moments that I enjoyed, which was clever with the top spinning with the sound fading in the background, leaving the viewer wondering whether they're still in Dom Cobb's dream or whether it's reality. Other than that, I found the film cold, with superficial characters that needed better character development. The film should have spent more time on sound storytelling (rather than rushing the film and spending a lot of time on concept explanation) that would have made the film compelling enough to hold my interest.

"Inception" is, technically speaking, a masterpiece. Surprisingly enough, the story and the screenplay in general are even more stunning than the visuals are! One is never quite certain what is going on - is it all a dream, or is it reality - which is the theme that goes across the whole film.
With an amazingly original screenplay by director Christopher Nolan, it is hard for "Inception" to leave you without thinking. It is actually a rather engaging film, and I cannot imagine many people walking out from the film thinking that it did not offer food for thought, if nothing else.
The visual effects are stunning, and in the same class as were the ones from "The Matrix" back in the day. Surely, it is not as breathtaking as "Avatar" was, but that was not it's intention in the first place. It is just visually a great film.
The cast was also rather superb, especially DiCardo, Gordon-Levitt and Cottilard. Not really amazing performances, but definitely good and not over the top, which would have brought the quality of the film down.
Christopher Nolan's direction and imagination are at it's peak - he has definitely surpassed "The Dark Knight" by far, with this film. Definitely a new masterpiece of cinema, that will leave no one apathetic.

I know A LOT of people that would give Inception 5/5 (or more) simply because it was probably one of the best films of 2010.  I'm not trying to discredit it.  I enjoyed it greatly.  That said the one and only reason I'm giving it a 4.5/5 is the ending.  While the ending was a bit creative, it was by no means original and it made the film itself end on a flat note.  I had to stop myself from saying WHAT THE HELL JUST HAPPENED!  Aside from the ending though, I can defiantly see why Inception received such praise.  The film features some big stars who not only work together perfectly but also put on excellent performances.  The most well-known of the stars by all means was Leonardo DiCaprio who continues to amaze us with his acting.  I don't think the director (Christopher Nolan) needs any introduction.  He's made himself famous in filmmaking for the past 10 years and Inception is no exception.  Inception uses one of the few concepts left in filming that hasn't quite met its full potential.  With Inception however, the story easily delivers some truly mind-opening ideas.  And of course what would a summer blockbuster be without its dazzling effects and explosive action.  Inception isn't just dazzling and explosive; it has some of the most breath-taking images and intense action sequences that have ever hit the big screen.  I can't think of many films that left me so stunned.  Complex, inventive, exciting, and super ambitious, Inception is that rare summer blockbuster that succeeds viscerally, visually, and intellectually.

I feel torn about this movie.  My feelings after this viewing are the same as when I first saw it in the theaters.  On one hand I appreciate the intricacies and just the pure scale in design of the story.  I enjoy exploring the depths of our subconscious in such a visceral and physical way-- as in physically jumping into layers of subconscious.  On the other hand, I feel that this style of storytelling is rather forceful.  Seems like in every scene there is some new "rule" to this dream world.  And as audience we have to buy it immediately, or else we'd be lost in the story.  One may argue that this is a device to keep the audience on edge.  The other way, the way I felt while watching it, is that-- I am your storytelling puppet, I will believe as I am told.  In fact, the whole movie is based on this preamble.  So in that case, if I choose to not dive headfirst into this premise, I could really care less who is a "projection"  and who is "real", who is sedated and who needs a kick, who is in limbo and who can be resuscitated.  I could care less who has "subconscious security".  The matter of fact is-- if it's all a dream, why does all the guns and the shootouts and the explosions matter.  I believe that if they filmmakers had taken out all the spectacles of the movie, it would still be a interesting story, or perhaps an even more compelling one.  The underlying arc is the tragic love story between Cobb and his wife.  The rest is simply eye candy.
